editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

div.p: As it hath been often played in the black friars, by the children of the revels.
Imprinted at London, and are to be sold by John Hodgets in Paul's churchyard. 1606.

div.stage: Â¶. Enter severally 3. Gentlemen, as to see a play.

sp.p: How now gallants, what is't? what is't?
The I'll of gulls.
The I'll of gulls, what should that be?
A play by the name, but come shall's quarter ourselves?
If some had had the wit to do so in time, they might ha' saved the hangman a labour. But come boy, furnish us with stools.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Pardon me sir, my office is to speak a prologue, not to provide you stools.
And you were the epilogue to sir -
Fie be not incivil: dost hear youth, prithee what's he that discovered your new found land, the I'll of gulls? what is he?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: A mere stranger sir.
A stranger? the better welcome: comes he eastward, westward, or northward ho?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: None of the three ways I assure you.
Prithee where is he?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Not on his knees in a corner, to Apollo praying that his play may hold in a good hand at passage, not on the stage amongst gallants, preparing a bespoke plaudite; but close in his study writing hard, to get him a handsome suit against summer.
And where sits his friends? hath he not a prepared company of gallants, to applaud his jests, and grace out his play.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: None I protest: do poets use to bespeak their auditory.
The best in grace do, and but for that, some that I know, had never had their grace in poetry till this day.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Then must our author look for a certain disgrace, for he is altogether unfurnished of such a friendly audience.
Then he must lay his trial upon God and good wits. But why doth he call his play the I'll of gulls, it begets much expectation.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p:
Not out of any dogged disposition, not that it figures a ãâ¦ã certain state, or private government: far be that supposition ãâã
the thought of any indifferent auditor: and the argument being a little string or rivulet, drawn from the full strain of the right worthy gentleman, sir Philip Sydney's well known Archadea, confirms it: only a Duke to make trial of certain experiments, retires with his retinue into a nameless desert. Now as well for fashion's sake, as that all those which have to do in that desert, are gulled in the reach of their hopes, therefore he calls it, (And as he presumes, not improperly) the I'll of gulls.

Out a question he hath promised thee some fee, thou pleadest so hard for him, but and he be a right poet he will never perform it. But what method observes he in his play, is't any thing critical? Are lawyers fees, and citizens' wives laid open in it: I love to hear vice anatomized, and abuse let blood in the master vain, is there any great man's life charactered in't?

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: None I protest sir, only in the person of Dametas he expresses to the life the monstrous and deformed shape of vice, as well to beget a loathing of abuse, as that his villainy may give the greater luster to the virtuous dispositions of trueborn gentility.
All that's nothing to me, and there be not wormwood water and copperes in't, I'll not like it, should Apollo write it, and Rosius himself act it.

Fie upon thee, thou art too too critical: is there any good bawdry in't, jests of an ell deep, and a fathom broad, good cuckolding, may a couple of young-setters up learn to do well in't? Give me a scene of venery, that will make a men's spirits stand on their tiptoes, and die his blood in a deep scarlet, like your Ovid's ars amandi, there flows the true springhead of poetry, and the very crystal fount of Parnassus.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Chaste ears would never endure it sir.
Chaste ears, now deafness light upon 'em, what should chaste ears do at a play.
'Tis strange now, I am of neither a both your opinions, I like neither railing nor bawdry: no, give me a stately penned history, as thus, the rugged winds, with rude and ragged ruffs. Etc.
Fie upon't, mere fustian; I had rather hear two good bawdy jests, than a whole play of such teare-cat thunderclaps.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p:
Alas gentlemen, how is't possible to content you? you will ãâã railing, and invectives, which our author neither dares, nor
affects: you bawdy and scurrile jests, which neither becomes his modesty to write, nor the ear of a generous auditory to hear: you must ha' swelling comparisons, and bombast epithets, which are as fit for the body of a comedy, as Hercules' shoe for the foot of a pygmy: yet all these we must have, and all in one play; or 'tis already condemned to the hell of eternal disgrace.
Look to't, if there be not gall in't, it shall not pass.
If it be not bawdy, 'tis impossible to pass.
If it be both critical and bawdy, if it be not high written, both your poet and the house to, lose a friend of me.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Nay I beseech you sir, if you be his friend, stand so to him still, for he hath too many enemies already, in whose judgements, he and his labours stand excommunicate, as though unworthy to present themselves in this assembly.
Enemies, nays foot then there's some hope in's play, for envy never works but against desert and merit. If he be envied there's some worth in him, and I'll see out his play for that only.
Faith and I'll see an act or two out, but I tell you aforehand I cannot see it out.
Not see it out? your reason.
Fore God I lay in bed till passed three o'clock , slept out my dinner, and my stomach will toll to supper afore five, therefore you must pardon me.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: Either see it all or none; for 'tis grown into a custom at plays, if any one rise (Especially of any fashionable sort) about what serious business soever, the rest thinking it in dislike of the play, though he never thinks it, cry mew, by Jesus vild; and leave the poor heartless children to speak their epilogue to the empty seats.
Why dost think thy audience like a flock of sheep, that one cannot leap over a hedge, but all the rest will follow, they ha' more of reason in them then so.
Well, I'll sit out the play, and be but to avoid that sheepish imputation, but see it be bawdy, or by this light I and all my friends will hiss.

sp.speaker: Prologue
sp.p: You should not deal gentlemanlike with us else.

sp.speaker: Prologue.
sp.l: The misery that waits upon the pen
Of the best writers, judge it gentlemen,
Let them express the very soul of wit,
and want opinions voice to countenance it,
'Tis like the idle buzzing of a fly,
Heard, not regarded: wretched poetry:
If 'a write mirth, 'tis ribaldry, and mean,
Scorned of chaste ears. If he compose a scene
Of high writ poesy, fitting a true stage,
'Tis counted fustian: if portick rage
Strike at abuse, or open the vain of sin,
He is straight informed against for libelling.
Neither quick mirth, invective, nor high state,
Can content all: such is the boundless hate
Of a confused audience: then we
That scarcely know the rules of poesy
Cannot scape check. Yet this our comfort is,
The wise will smile to hear th' impartial hiss.
We neither brag, nor tremble, faint nor entreat,
Our merits nothing, yet our hopes are great,
Yet this our author bade me boldly speak,
His play shall pass, let envy swell and break,
Detraction he scorns, honours the best,
Tanti for hate; thus low to all the rest.

div.head: Actus primi. scaena prima.
div.stage: Â¶ Enter Basilius, Gynetia, Hipolita, Violetta, lord attendants.

sp.speaker: Basil:
sp.p: Welcome gallants, welcome honoured bloods; the reason that we have unclothed us of our princely government in Arcadia, and have to do with this private retirement here in this desert I'll, you shall find in that schedule, only thus much for public satisfaction: 'tis not strange to you, that the choicest treasure nature endowed us with, is mind up in the veins of my two daughters: how much their quiet, and the smooth stream of our government in Arcadia, was troubled by the impetuous concourse of unruly suitors, is familiar with your knowledge; this to avoid, I have for my image there in my absence appointed my brother, and undertook this private retirement.

sp.speaker: Gy.
sp.p: Why my lord, are you so covetous of your daughter's beauties, that their perfections shall be a means to hinder their preferment?

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: Rather to further it fair Queen: they are the only pearls of our age, and to see them well set in honourable and well-befitting
sp.l: Marriage, is our wishes' happiness.
To which effect we have sent a general challenge
To all the youthful bloods of Africa,
That whosoever (Born of princely stem)
Dares foot the bosom of this desert I'll,
(The stage where I'll perform this lover's prize)
And by his wit and active policy,
Woo, win, entice, or any way defeat
Me of my charge, my daughters of their hearts,
Shall with their loves wear my imperial crown
Wreathe of their conquest.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: A prize, a prize, rare work for fencers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: What coward would not venture a cracked crown for such a booty?

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.l: To that intent our island is fenced in
By sea and land, and at each corner built
A castle for defence, which like great men
Do overlook Archadea: over which,
We have appointed captains. More to desire,
Is more than we are willing to discover.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Well then sister, I see we must to haphazard for husbands.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: God send me one with a good face and I care not.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Love and be thy will, send me one with a fair table in his forehead, like time.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay, and his face be good, let me alone to trick his forehead, a country-gentlewoman taught me how: but father I wonder how you dare undertake such a peremptory challenge against all comers, considering you have been so long troubled with an ague.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: An ague? what ague?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why your quotidian, Dametas the court surfeit, he that dwells in your eye, like a disease in your blood.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: And the presence were not exceeding empty-stomackt, it would never digest such almes-basket-scraps, the very fall and garbage of gentry; fie upon him, he becomes the great chamber worse than a gentleman-usher with wry legs.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: He is the most mishapen suit of gentility that ever the court wore.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Had he not been of my father's own making, I should ha' condemned his tailor for an exceeding butcher.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: If you retain the love of children, or the duty of subjects, express it in your obedience, we know Dametas loves us.

sp.speaker: Vilet.
sp.p: As captains and courtiers do old widows, for profit and preferment.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: In sign whereof we make him.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, you have bestowed too much of the making of him up already.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The very making of him up, has stood you in more than the whole our sides worth.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: In my free thoughts you wrong him, therefore to express our love, and to give the world public note of his loyalty, we create him your guardian.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: How father, my guardian.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: I minion, yours.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Do you hear father, bid him bespeak spectacles, for my fingers have vowed to have a blind match with his eyes.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Well said Haggart, I'll make your proud heart stoop to the lure of obedience. But come, by this time our challenge is published, and our gallants wits sweating in the field of invention, and it behoves us not to rest unexercised.
sp.l: So to our lodge, in the mean time be it known,
Our breath has power to raise, or cast men down.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Now captain observation, time's bawd, thou that hast kept the age's door, whilst upstart baseness crept into the bed of greatness, what dost thou think of this change?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: That it pleased the Duke, and becomes not subjects to examine his actions.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: That's no part of my meaning, yet would I gladly be better instructed why the Duke broke up his court in Archadea, and removed it into this island?

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I am not secretary to his thoughts, but the general mmour is, that out of the freeness of his spirit, he hath sent a challenge to all his neighbour princes, that whosoever (Within a twelvemonth ) can defeat him of his daughters, shall with their loves, enjoy his dukedom, the garland proposed for the victors.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Your words throw sense into me, and that's the cause the island is so surely guarded with watch-towers, over which ourselves
and other captains have the charge.

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: And to the end, that not affection, but desert may prove victor, are the two ladies so narrowly observed, the one never out a the eye of her father, the other continually in the lodge of Dametas, the Duke's chief director.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: If inquisitiveness be not too bold a guest, what do you think of Dametas.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: As of a little hillock, made great with others ruins.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your comparison holds, for by report, his avarice has unmade many to make him up.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: How did he first stumble on the prince's favour?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: As some do upon offices, by fortune and flattery, or as truth says, the prince having one day lost his way, wandering in the woods found this Dametas, affected his discourse, took him along to the court, and like great men in love with their own doings, countenanced his defects, gave him offices, titles, and all the additions that go to the making up of a man worshipful.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: I cannot but commend the Duke for raising him, nor yet praise him, that he proportions not his carriage answerable to his fortunes.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Your thoughts and mine are twins in that: but I hear the warning bell, some strangers are arrived.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Let's to our office then, and conduct them to Dametas, whose custom is to spit and hem, whilst his scribe maior takes their examinations.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Manasses, how dost like my play at tennis?

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: You play well sir, but you lose still.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Policy Manasses, policy, for when any man upbraids me with my gettings at court, I may swear truly I have lost more than I have got bite.

sp.speaker: Manas
sp.p: By the tennis court I think you have.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: If by any court, 'tis enough to save mine oath.
But what do our spruce witted gallants say of my bounty.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Faith sir according to the proportion of it, little or nothing they say 'tis a bankrupt, and dares not show his head.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p:
Then let 'em leave resting at me, though it please the Duke for some few good parts that he sees in me, to make me his familiar,
I scorn to be public, or every courtier's companion: but who comes here?
sp.stage: Enter the two captains, with aminter and Julio two princes, attired one like a poor soldier, the other like a poor scholar.
sp.p: The captains of the watch-towers? what news with you.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: A couple of petitioners, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Had I best take their petitions Manasses?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: O in any case, though you never peruse 'em, 'tis the only course in request.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fellows, deliver your petitions to my scribe mayor, and dost hear, put 'em up Manasses, they may be wrongs to us.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: And they be, I hope they be not the first wrongs I have put up for your worship.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: That fellow's pocket is like a tailor's hell, it eats up part of every man's due: 'tis an executioner, and makes away more innocent petitions in one year, than a redheaded hang man cuts ropes in an age.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now, what are you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: A poor soldier an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Poor soldiers do not like my worship, they are bad members.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: Then if they had a woman to their judge, they should be sure to be cut off, for they cannot endure bad members in a commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What are you?

sp.speaker: Iuiso.
sp.p: A poor scholar, an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Poor scholars do not like our worship neither, they rail against rich cormorants, they are bad members to.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: Cut them off both sir, and make the land an eunuch.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll take order with 'em I warrant thee, and I may have my will, I'll ha' neither poor scholar nor soldior about the court.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: The next way to make it the I'll of fools.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What's he talks of fools there? why how now sir, know you to whom you speak?

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Cry your worship mercy, I had forgotten your authority.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p:
But I remember well enough I warrant you, I command you, in my name and the Duke's, to attend your guard, and you regard me no more than a careless lawyer doth an undone cliant,
but I'll inform: the Duke shall know, out, pack.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Command your slave's sir, we are gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why so I hope are we sir, and of the best and last edition, of the Duke's own making.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Cry your authority mercy, will you discharge us of these passengers?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: You are discharged, about your business.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: Bad fate, that wrong should set his foot on right, and true born eagles stoop to this base kite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What an excellent trade it is to be an officer maker, I'll have more officers, and one shall be to keep scholars and soldiers out of the court, for they dare not come in the great chamber already, for want of good clothes. But gods me Manasses, go tell the Duke I must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: Presently sir, I'll go fetch the head to give the foot a posset: and my master had wit to his villainy, he would make an excellent dish for the hangman.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Right worshipful.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Ay sir, I know my place is worshipful, I tell thee knave I could hang thee by my patent, if it were granted once, I'll tell thee how it runs, it allows me 24 knaves, 6 knights, 10 fools, 13 felons, and 14 traitors by the year, take 'em how, why, when, and where I please.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I do not think the Duke will ever grant it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why not grant it? why should you think he will not grant it. Such another word and I'll send you to limbo instantly.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: We thank you good Dametas.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: I hope you'll take reasonable bail for our forthcoming.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: The case is altered with you since you came out of Archadea.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: My honourable friends, Julio and Aminter, myself and the best ability of my power, lies at your service.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: You see how confidently we presume upon your letters promise, in furthering us to attain the lover's prize.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Duke's daughters are your own, and in a word thus shall you attain 'em, some 3 days hence I will appoint a hunting, to which I will invite the Duke and both his daughters: in this hunt will I upon some sudden occasion divide the train âª and having singled out the two does, I hope you have wit enough to strike.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: To strike, how mean you.

sp.speaker: Dametas.
sp.p: As headsmen do, of with their maidenheads, or if the Duke offer resistance, of with his crown to.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: That were violence, and clean opposite to the intent of the challenge.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Come ye are shallow, to't vi et armis, to't, I'll be your second, think of the crown, ha my letters travailed for you, my wit wrought for you, and my invention sweat for you, to possess you of your loves, and seat you in the dukedom, and come you now with 'tis violence, and against the intent of the challenge, I am ashamed to hear you.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Nay Dametas, and your resolution be so forward, ours shall overtake you, we doubted least the preferments your lord hath heaped upon you, had smothered your affection to us ward.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: That was the father that begotten the doubt in us, you will appoint the hunt.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Sever the Duke, divide the train, and then.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: We ha' your meaning.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Put it in execution then, but first entertain some new disguise, as at our next meeting I'll inform you. Adieu, I shall think long till I see you again.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: As a lawyer doth for his cliant for a second see. Here's no Judas?

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Yes, and a damned one to, for he would betray and sell his master.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: 'Tis common in such base fellows, such court-spyders, that weave their webs of flattery in the ears of greatness, if they can once entangle them in their quaint treachery, they poison 'em straight.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: They are like unnecessary worms, whom the son of greatness creates of the gross and slimy multitude, as soon as they recover strength, they eat into the credit of true born gentry, undermine and work out the true nobility, to enroot and establish themselves.

sp.speaker: Am.
sp.p: And in the end, like Esop's starved snake, having leapt the sweet milk of greatness, made themselves strong in authority and friends, they turn their stings of envy into their preservers bosom.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
The example lives in this Dametas, who notwithstanding the Duke hath raised him to that height that he looks equal with himself, yet for the base hope of incertain government, he offers him
to sale, but let his treason live to the last minute.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: For my part I'll make that use of him that physicians do of poison, use as much of him as serves for mine honest intent, and cast down the rest, as unfit for any necessary employment.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Let our carriage in this attempt put on no show of violence either to the Duke, or his daughters.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: And let our discourse go so smoothly apparelled, that it move not the patience of the most tender ear.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: About it then, though his intent be base,
Our enterprise shall wear a noble face.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Archadea, thou heaven, within whose sphere
The star that guides my motion is fixed,
I court thy gracious bosom with a kiss
For this admittance: in thine amorous arms
Fair Violetta, fairer than the flower
That christened her, and graced her with that name
Do play the wanton:
Only her father like a covetous churl,
Owner of that unvalued diamond,
Hath made this desert I'll th'unwilling chest
In which he locks her. But the fair advantage
Of this large challenge, and my stars to friend,
Aided by this disguise, I shall break open
His iron casket, and enlarge my hope.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: This way she went sir, this way.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: But I say this way, I would thou shouldst know, we old courtiers can hunt a coney, and put her to the squeak, and make her cry out like a young married wife of the first night.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.l: For more help, as some of them have done,
But there she is.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll upon her presently, dost hear me sirrah, thou vessel of infirmity, woman, and by thy outside little better than one of the wicked, come hither and show thyself before us, show thyself before Dametas.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Dametas, Lisander then dissemble,
For he's the man must work thy entrance.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What art thou, speak.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: My mother is the Queen of Amasons,
Myself a virgin, married unto arms
And bold achievements, who have paced the world
In quest of fair Autioste my sister:
And turning homeward, the inconstant winds
And wrathful Neptune cast me on this shore.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And what's your business now you are landed?

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: My business is private with the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The Duke is busy, and shall speak with nobody .

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: I beseech you sir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: 'Tis no beseeching matter I assure you.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: No, never beseech for the matter, for except you could beseech with the tongue of angels, 'tis to no purpose with him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, I have heard thy master is a very good man where he takes.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: True, where he takes he is, but he takes nothing of you, and therefore look for no kindness from him.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Good, and dost thou take after thy master?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: No madam, I take commonly afore my master, for where he takes, he takes all, and leaves nothing for me to take.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: O, I feel your meaning.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: Let my master have some feeling of yours, and he'll preset your suit.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: 'Tis not the Duke's pleasure petitioners should buy their access.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: All's one, 'tis my master's pleasure, and usual fashion.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: And I must maintain the fashion. Worshipful Dametas, my late shipwreck as you see, hath made a defeat both of my friends and treasure, notwithstanding, fortune hath reserved me one jewel, which if I might request your worship in love to accept, and be a means to work my admittance to the Duke, I should become a true debtor to your love.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Well madam, though I hate nothing more than a man that takes bribes, yet pressed by your importunity, and that you tender it in love, lest I might seem too nice to withstand a lady's favour, I'll wear it for your sake, and if the Duke be not too busily employed, work your access.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: So doing, you shall perform the office of a dear-bought friend.

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: How quickly the tide's turned, but do you hear madam, though I take neither afore nor after my master, yet take my counsel, and do not trust my master: if you have a suit to the Duke keep it to yourself, for if you trust my master with it, he'll prefer it for you, but he'll begged for himself.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: That's plain cozenage.

sp.speaker: Ma
sp.p: Fie no, 'tis cunning in him, marry 'twould be though little better than cozenage in a country gentleman: but he returns.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Madam, I have been earnest, very earnest with the Duke for your admittance.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: And have you wrought it?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I have, marry you must think I bestowed much labour in't.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: 'Tmay be you did.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: 'Tmay be you did: and look a scance like a pothecary's wife pounding colliquintida, have my brains sweat for this.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Why the jewel is right Dametas, had I but an ass that would sweat me such pearl.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: An ass? and sweat such pearl, I'll bar her admittance, here take your jewel, the Duke will allow no admittance, and I will keep you back.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Keep me back, thou couldst do no more and I were a poor man's petitioner.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: And I'll do so much being a rich petitioner.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: You cannot sir. You court spaniel, you unnecessary mushroom, that in one night art sprung out of the root of greatness, I have bought my admittance, and I'll hate in dspetto del fato.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I must admit her, these ladies are so inward with our tricks, there's no good to be done upon them: well madam, your admittance is open, will ye follow.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: With all my heart sir, I'll be the blind man and poor petitioner, and thou shalt play the court spaniel with the silver bell, and I cad me into the presence.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.l: Court spaniel? mum: I'll bosom what I think,
Old Gibs not blind, I see although I wink.

div.stage: Enter Demetrias a prince, attired like a woodman, with him his page.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Boy, how dost like me in this attire?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: As the audience do a bad play, scurvily.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Is it not strange a prince should be thus metamorphosed?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Not so strange as the metamorphosis of Aiax and like your grace.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Grace you aggot: hast not forgotten that yet?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: No, and yet 'tis a wonder I ha' not, grace being so seldom used, I'm sure they say none at some ordenaries, for at sitting down they cannot intend it for hunger, and at rising up, they are either drunk, or have such mind a dice, they never remember, my lord then.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: No more lord, sirrah.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Indeed there are many already, but is not this strange, that rich men should forsake their titles? master then.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Your will sir.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: You have left many countries behind you in seeking your friend Lisander, and yet you cannot find him.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: True sir.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I ha' seen much gold lying upon Lombard's stalls, and could never finger penny of it.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Nay, 'twas not well sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: What conclude you then?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: That you were best sit down, and see what you ha' got by your journey.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I have seen a face as beautiful as heaven.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: That's nothing, a prisoner sees the face of heaven itself, when he looks but out at the prison-gate, I'll stand root, a man were as good be hanged, so a meet a handsome hangman, and a strong rope, as be in love.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Your reason for that.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Marry this sir, hanging is end of all troubles, and love the beginning. Nay further, I think a lord cannot be saved, for he is of all religions.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your proof for that.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: This; he thinks with the atheist there's no God but his mistress, with the infidel no heaven but her smiles, with the papist no purgatory but her frowns, and with the family of love, hold it lawful to lie with her, though she be another man's wife.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So sir, what follows?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Serving men sir, the master goes in before his wife, and the servingman follows his master.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Sirrah forbear, I must meditate.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: As the usurer before he parts with money, meditate upon the assurance.

div.stage: Enter Lisander privately, and overhears them.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: If Violettaes presence ha' not quenched
The memory of all things but herself,
I should be more familiar with that fate.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I have left my country to seek out my friend.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: And I my country and my friend for love.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: And in the search of him have lost myself
In the strange region of a woman's eye.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: In love, and in Archadea.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: As much as heaven transcends the humble earth,
So towers her praise, her face differs as far
From others, as a glow worm from a star.
She is a Princess that my soul affects.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And rich.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Half heir unto this dukedom.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: And she were whole heir to the four moral virtues, 'twere nothing: when shall I see the time that men will love for virtue, or a rich heir marry a poor wench without a portion, never I think.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Had not my friend Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: What of me?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: L ãâ¦ã nt in Thrace.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.l: We had never met in love,
His syllables betray him. I arrest you.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: At whose suit.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: Not at his tailors in any case, for there's no greater stitch to a younger brother's conscience, than to pay for a suit of apparel when 'tis worn out.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Lisander or his ghost.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: Demetrius,
Or some illusive tenant in his shape.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Unkind, why didst thou leave my company?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.l: For that which made the amorous god's leave heaven,
For love: but why is Demetrius thus disguised?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: For that which would make a jackanapes a monkey, and he could get it: a tail.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Peace rogue.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Why wag, is thy master in love?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p:
Faith sir he hath entered his action in Cupid's court, and means
to proceed in the suit it should seem.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Why didst not take my counsel in thy choice?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Because I feared a chiding, for doubting thine honourable thoughts would not have consented to my effeminate attempts, I stole this secret course, and manner of disguise, as best helping to access, which it hath begotten, now what access will bring forth, I commit to unborn industry.

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: It cannot but be prosperous: only the strict observance of our loves, hinders the passage of our hopes.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Indeed that's not the least hindrance, yet the Duke himself, and my quaint disguise hath removed it out of my way, who not only takes me for a woman, but hath allowed me for my love's companion.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Fortune deals kindly with thee, I am as far from access to my love, as when I was in thrate.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Dametas is the oystershell that holds thy pearl, our wits must fish for him.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Will the cod's head bite?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Like an old usurer at a young heir's inheritance, and I h'ate ready hooked for him: and he ere he comes, my plot is to prefer thee to his service.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Prithee do, and I'll serve him in his right kind.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Dametas, my love is yours.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Which madam I am as proud of

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: As a malcontent of a change, or an old lady of a new fashion.

sp.speaker: Li:
sp.p: To be round I have a suit to you in the behalf of this woodman

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: To me sweet blossom, though I be somewhat strict in mine office, I cannot be stony to ladies. Fellow is thy petition drawn?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Petition.

sp.speaker: Manas:
sp.p: Your only way to move a ãâã by: humbly complaining to your good worship, oh 'tis most pathetic, and indeed without money, can do just nothing with authority.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Come hither stripling whose son wert thou?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: I am not so wise a child as you take me for, I never knew my father.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Didst not know thy father?

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: A common fault, his betters forget themselves when they grow rich, then blame not him to forget his father.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What was his name?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: If I may give credit to my mother, they called him Menalchas, who on his deathbed made me his heir, with this charge, to seek your worship's service, and gave me this gold as a remembrance to purchase your favour.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Gold him?

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.p: Now doth my master long more to finger that gold, than a young girl married to an old man, doth to run her husband? ashore at cuckold's haven.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Well, I could do for this fatherless youth.

sp.speaker: Ma:
sp.p: As many executors and overseers have done, cheat him of his portion, and then turn him out of doors a-begging .

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: But for I have the guardian ship of the prince, I dare do nothing without the consent of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Come come sir, your worship shall not refuse him.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Well then I woe not, but 'tis for your sake I assure you.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Meaning the gold.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What shall I call thy name?

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Dorus an't like your worship.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Ah, good Dorus, be an honest youth Dorus, reverence your master, and love yourself: be sure to get under me, and you shall lose nothing in my service. Madam, the Duke and Duchess expect you at the hunt, and await your coming at Diana's oak.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: I'll attend them presently, be a good servant Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: 'Twill be his own another day madam.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: In the mean time let it be yours to lead the way.

sp.speaker: Dametas
sp.p: My service doth attend you,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As the pursuivant doth the prisoner for a double fee.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: Welcome slave to a slave, a fair presage,
The hope of love sweetens love's vassalage.

div.stage: Enter aminter and Julio, attired like satires.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: Now and Dametas be the mettle he was stamped for, a right villain.

sp.speaker: Julio
sp.p: And he be not, hang him.

sp.speaker: Am:
sp.p: Nay he deserves hanging to if he be: but will you trust him?

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p:
Yes as far as I see him, and he that trusts him further my
trust is he will be deceived.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: Indeed, he that will prove false to his maker, will be true to no man.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.p: Yes for the present time, like a bawd to him that gives most.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: That's not for love.

sp.speaker: Iul:
sp.p: Yes of the money: he that looks for other love in this age. This is the place his letter speaks of, and here he comes himself.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Why so lo: now is the web of my hopes upon the loom of perfection, and in this quench of lashes Aminter and Julio.
sp.l: See and see not, all mum, you know your que,
The games your own, if you can hunt it true.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Dametas, were thine ears ever at a more musical banquet? how the hounds mouths like bells are tuned one under another like a slothfulness, the speed of the cry outran my sense of hearing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Cross over the forest to Diana's oak my liege, and there your grace advantaged by the height of the ground, shall not only at pleasure hear, but be eye-witness of their musical contention.

sp.speaker: Bas.
sp.p: Thanks good Dametas, be thy directions our wives convoy.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Where is his highness' Dametas?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: At Adonis' bower madam, where he expects your presence to see the fleshing of a couple of Spartan hounds, in the wasting blood of the spent deer.

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.p: Thanks good Dametas, mine eyes would not be good friends with my feet, should they not bring 'em to that kingly sport.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Sweet ladies, to save you the expense of much breath âª which must be laid out in the purchase of the game. I have provided you this stand, from whence your eyes may be commanders of the sport: such sport as you little dream of.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.l: We are your love's debtors kind Dametas.
As I love virtue I pity these poor beasts,
These sylvan commoners, to see what tasks
Our covetous foresters impose upon them,
Who not content with impost of their breath,
(Poor hearts,) pursue them smiling to their death.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: 'Twas the end of their creation madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: So was the end of ours to live in peace,
And not to tyrannize on harmless beasts,
But foresters, like images set forth
The tyranny of greatness without pity,
As they the deer, so covetous wealth pursues
The trembling state of their inferiors.
And to clasp up the volume of their sins,
They drink their blood, and clothe them with their skins,
Then cease to press poor beasts with tyranny,
You love your lives, think they are loath to die.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: You are too tender-hearted to be a good huntswoman lady.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: And some of you too hard-hearted, but leaving this discourse of hunting, have all our gallantry of Lacedaemon and Greece, spent the vigour of their wits, that not one dares venture.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: For our love's sister, you may see the properer women, the worse luck.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Tush you shall have suitors, fear not madam.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: No at any hand sister, for with a fear it comes.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then I'll fear of purpose, because I would have 'em come.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And they do not, they are notable cowards.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Then let 'em keep away still, for I have vowed my maidenhead shall never do homage to the bed of a coward.

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: Sweet ladies, will you beguile a minute or two with this discourse, till I step up to the top of the hill, and make discovery of the game,

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Let your return be speedy good Dametas.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I'll put on wings and fly.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Out of the court, and the whole country shall have a good riddance.

sp.speaker: Amin:
sp.p: So, he hath put 'em fair to the stand, let's issue and surprise them,

sp.speaker: Julio:
sp.p: Be resolute and sudden.

div.stage: Aminter and Julio, issue out and bear them away.

sp.speaker: Viol:
sp.p: Murder, treason, rescue, help.

div.stage: Enter first Dametas, and then the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Yes much rescue, much help, much Dametas: why so, this lest was drawn home close to the head, it cannot choose but cleave the very white of our hopes, the Duke's wit âto thy tackle good wit, some sudden sea room, or our stratagem is run a ground.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p:
Tell me Dametas, was not the dear a prodigal, did he not
spend his breath freely amongst us?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: And his blood too my liege, but did you observe how the hounds like politicians nosed out the game?

sp.speaker: Ba
sp.p: True: and coming to the loss Melampus, but where are our daughters?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Did you observe that my liege, that Melampus as a true hound is ever hoarse cheered or hollow, yet he kept time to.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Certain Dametas, but where are our daughter's man?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Busy my lord under a brake bush, disputing of the virtue of sweet water, and ground ivy.

div.stage: Cry within, treason, murder, rescue, help.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: What cry of treasons that Dametas?
Pray God no danger sets upon my daughters,
Seek out our wife, I'll haste unto their rescue.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And my sword unemployed? allegiance: says nay to that my liege, I am for the adventure myself, if they be surprised (I am a mad man) your grace shall hear more: if not (ãâã the more sorry) your grace shall hear more to: make peace with your thoughts till my return, and doubt not their recovery.

div.stage: Enter the Duchess with her daughters, Dametrius, Lisander. Etc.

sp.speaker: Gyn.
sp.p: Speak, where's the Duke?

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: Here my Genitia.
What mean these weapons, are our daughters safe?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: As a thief in a ãâ¦ã ill father, we thank our redeemers.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: The more my grief, were you surprised then madam?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Yes say Dametas.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: And how sweet ladies, and how were you rescued?

sp.speaker: Gyne.
sp.l: Being surprised, this gallant Amason
Pressed to their rescue, had you seen what worth
She and this woodman spent in our defence,
Wonder would ha' bereft you of all sense.
She raised her sword with such a manly grace,
As had nor her mild sex controlled my thoughts,
I could have fallen in love with her high worth.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.l: You over price us madam, not our desert
But the weak spi ãâ¦ã of our opposites.
Gave leisure to the di ãâ¦ã nes of our worth.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.l: It please your modesty to lesson it.
But it shall still live great in our regard. What woodman's that?

sp.speaker: Dame:
sp.p: My follower my liege.

sp.speaker: Basil:
sp.l: Whatever he be, he hath deserved our love.
Fellow be near us, and for this desert,
Performed against those traitors to our blood,
Under thy master we give thee an attendant,
To guard the life and safety of our daughter.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Thank you good father, whoever lose by the bargain, I ha' got me a servant by the match: wot serve me fellow?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.l: In the best I can.
In heart your fellow, though in show your man.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: I'll try your dubious service: I command,
Your knee to kiss the ground, your lip my hand.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Pardon me madam.

sp.speaker: Hippol.
sp.l: Here's hot love no doubt,
I may command my man, and go without.

sp.speaker: Basil:
sp.l: Truce to this airy war, these paper bullets
Better become a closet than a park,
The forest music is to hear the hounds
Rend the thin air, and with a lusty cry
Awake the drowsy echo, and confound
Their perfect language in a mingled sound,
Then so the court, our forest sport being done,
A second chase of lovelier sport's begun.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.l: If fortune cross not what our hopes pursue,
Our fears have met their deaths, our loves their due.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: Crossed in my hopes, the ladies rescued, and the princes like cravens beat out of the game-place, my invention must turn traveler for more stratagems what and I should discover their plot to the Duke, attach 'em for traitors, and beg their lands for my labour; though they be my friends, 'twere a pretty parcel of policy.
sp.l: All things are lawful that do profit bring,
A wiseman's bow goes with a twofold string.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p:
Did ever two princes meet such strange changes in their loves? now we have wrought our admittance, and in a manner got
'em into our possessions, our hopes like false fires having brought us within âen, vanish, and leave us out of all comfort.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: That the Duke should dote upon thee for a woman, makes for our purpose, but that the Duchess should be enamoured on thee for a man, is preposterous.

sp.speaker: Lasan.
sp.p: Whether my ãâã shown in the rescue of the ladies, or the ardent glances her daughter's beauty steals from mine eyes, give her thoughts encouragement, I know not, but her hopes stand confident I am a man, and for that cause am I barred from access.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: I way thy counterfeit ãâ¦ã rances by mine own, for though by the Duke's allowance I am her privileged attendant, yet such is the devillishness of Dametas, that I cannot joy so much access as to confer with her.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I can compare my lord and his friend to nothing in the world so fitly as to a couple of water buckets, for whilst hope winds the one up, despair plunges the other down, whilst I like a harlequin in an Italian comedy, stand making faces at both their follies.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Well, since the shape of our proceeding grows so monstrous, let's cast our inventions in a new mould, and having so firm a foundation as this disguise to build upon, let's draw the model, and raise the whole frame of our attempts anew.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Indeed, lovers should be conditioned like tyrants, who having the aim of a crown in ãâ¦ã violently over all lets that intervent their course, and so must we.

sp.speaker: Lisan
sp.p: And so will we, my resolutions already bent, and if I shoot not, the next level I take, ãâ¦ã I beseech thee break thy bow about mine ears, and strike the horns in my forehead, for married men to hang their caps on.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: I have met a means ãâã my purpose already: Mopsa Dametas' only daughter, is ãâ¦ã in love with me, and to her I'll feign extreme ardour of affection, and make her the shadow under which I'll court the true substance of my divine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: About it then, I'll sweat my invention to death but I'll overtake thee; but here comes one of my ãâã. I must hear his importunity, for no reasonable denial will brush him of.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Zehnane.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: My liege.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p:
My thoughts come like a sail afore the wind, swollen big with news and thine ears the midwife must deliver me of this burden,
my Duchess is sick, heart sick for thee Zelmane.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: For me, why my lord, I am no rosa-solis, nor aqua mirabilis to recover sick folks.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: Shall I be short with thee? My lady's in love with thee.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: With me my lord.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: With thee my lady: her amorous glances are her accusers, her very looks write sonnets in thy commendations, she carves thee at board, and cannot sleep for dreaming on thee in bed, she's turned sun-riser, haunts private walks, and like a disgraced courtier, studies the art of melancholy.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Now alas good lady.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Nay never pity her, she deserves none, rather let's bend our endeavours to entangle her more. To see the kindness of fortune, who fearing we should be acquainted with solitude in this our 12 month retirement, hath begotten a domestical merriment, and made our own thoughts actors in't, and as bad a poet as I am, I'll ha' one scene in't of mine own invention.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Dametas will storm at that, for he cannot endure poetry should be countenanced: but how is't my liege?

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: 'Tis ready plotted already, and that the Duchess may not find thee unprovided when she comes to court thee

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Court me, court a woman my liege.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Why that's the very happiness of the jest, but in any case confess thyself a man.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: A man my liege, I ha' no colour fort.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Tush I'll furnish thee, say thou art some prince, no matter who, and haste to do with this disguise of purpose to court my daughter Violetta,

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Is this scene of your own inventing my liege?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Mine own i'faith, and to confirmed the rather, use more oft and private conference with my daughter, interchange discourse and amorous dalliance, o 'twill set my Duchess affections afire , to think her rivaled by her daughter, and give us smooth passage to our love.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: How occasion plays the wanton with me. Well my liege, do but you work my admittance to your daughter, and I'll bestow all the art I am worth in courting her, and see, as if fortune had a hand in our comedy, she hath entered the Duchess just at her que, shadow yourself in your ark, and leave me to give her entertainment.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Forget not to personate some prince in any case.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, I'll play the prince with much art.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: This way he went, on this sweet violet bed
Still dwells the print of his enamoured tread,
The deprest flowers have strengthened their sweet
By stealing amorous kisses from his feet.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Absolute poet, Penelope was a ballad-maker to her.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: O do not fly my presence, gentle wanton stay,
What have I found you, faith you runaway
I'll tie a chain about your waste for this,
And make you buy your freedom with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Fie madam, this courtesy is more than needs âª

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Be not so coy, let not a loving dame
Find thee less kind than senseless elements,
Thou never walkst, but the enamoured air
Like an officious lover bears thy train,
Whilst the cool wind doth with his velvet wing
Fan the thin air upon thy sweaty cheek,
Stealing sweet kisses from thy silken lip.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Shield this vain breath, beat at some lady's ear.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: But you are none, you are not, come you are not,
Your valour, looks, and gesture show you are not,
Your manly brow, and your commanding eye,
Where war and fortune dwell in majesty,
Your private walks, and varied passions,
Your glances to my daughter, sure you are not,
And my firm love is confident you are not.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: There's a lover of a right temper, she'll outface the name of her sex instantly.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well madam, sith your observation hath discovered me, upon promise of your secrecy I confess myself a man.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: Good, excellent, how truly she takes my directions.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I knew my judgement could not be deceived,
Nor durst proud love have done me so much wrong
To cast my thoughts unto a woman's eye.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: Love durst not, good, good, excellent, what next.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: But madam, now I am known to you, what further request you.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Exchange of looks, and freedom of thy bed,
Thy presence, thy embracements, thy kind love,
for which my amorous thoughts have long line sick.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Thank you good wife, nay and a Duchess long to give her husbands the horning, let it never grieve butchers to do homage at cuekold's haven.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Well madam, to give content to your affections, and in a strong hope you will mediate my suit to your daughter, sort out but fit time and opportunity, and master your desires.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: And he were a man now I might be rarely tupped.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Give me thy hand then, with this amorous kiss I seal thee mine.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: And I confirmed with this.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.p: Rare, rare, rare, she's his sealed and delivered in the presence of her husband.

sp.speaker: D.
sp.p: Now lest my husband should suspect our love,

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Now, what shadow for that now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Hear a good jest, persuade him thou'rt a woman.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: That's not to do now madam, for he as confidently believes and ardently courts me for a woman, as you for a man.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Good, excellent, maintain that humour still,
Seem coy, look nice, and as we women use,
Be mild and proud, embrace, and yet refuse.

sp.speaker: Basil.
sp.p: Excellent virtues in a woman.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I prithee do, 'twill be a scene of mirth
For me to quote his passions and his smiles,
His amorous behaviour, and how his eye
Will beget strange variety of looks.
And shoot 'em into thine, but the chief sports this
To see an old man with a young man kiss.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: To see an old Duchess a young lady kiss.
Now the plot packs the scenes all comical,
I cannot speak for laughter, to see these women
That would be counted wonders for their wit,
Lay plots to gull themselves, silly conceit,

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To take me for a man.

sp.speaker: Basi.
sp.l: And arm herself
To laugh at me, make jests and scoffs at me,
But soothe her humour, the revenge she'd throw
Upon my head, shall fall on her own brow.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p:
Upon you both, so, so, so, how greedily their inventions like bugles follows the scent of their own gullery, yet these are no fools,
God forbid, not they: but to the drift, mirth in my warm blood sits, laughing at this division of their wits.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Wot to believe me sister, I never eat a cherry, but it puts me in mind of a husband, it kisses my lips with such a harmless prettiness.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Now in good deed lo I love 'em a life to, I think I shall never ha' my belly full on 'em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Of what, not of husbands Violetta.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: No, of cherries Hipolita, but take heed of 'em, they be a very filling meat, and dangerous things for us maids I can tell you, we may surfeit after 'em presently.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Surfeit after what, a husband?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I and after cherries to Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I warrant you sister, an old lady in Lacedaemon taught me a preservative against that.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: For the love of cherries what.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Marry this it was, still said she, betwixt every cherry said she, be sure to crack a stone said she.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then let me alone, I'll crack a couple a stones betwixt every cherry, rather than surfeit on 'em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You must take heed you crack not too many to, for you may surfeit of the stone as well as of the cherry.

sp.speaker: Vi.
sp.p: Nay and they be such dangerous things, I have done with 'em.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: So have I to for this time, but sister, is it not a strange kind of servile liberty that we live in here in Archadea?

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: For all the world as Englishmen keep their felons, and Italians their wines, we never stir abroad without our jailors.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And for what cause forsooth, only to keep us from marriage.

sp.speaker: Vil.
sp.p: Sure 'tis either some high content, or extreme discommodity, that our father debars us of it.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: By this stone methinks I long like a woman with child, till I know the difference betwixt a maid and a wife.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Well, god a mercy of all cursen souls, I was near the knowledge on't last night I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: O that I had been with thee I might ha' been so to: for love of marriage how?

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: Why thus: as I lay slumbering in my bed,
No creature with me but my maidenhead:

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Is that a creature?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Some maintain it is.
Got in the eye, conceived in a kiss:
Others whose speech seem near akin to truth
Say 'tis a passion, bred ith' heat of youth,
Some call't a sigh, and some an amorous groan,
All differ in the definition,
But in the allowd opinion of most,
'Tis never truly had till it be lost.
But lying thus alone, as maids do use,
Methought I dreamt, as maids can hardly choose,
And in my dream methought 'twas too much wrong
A pretty maid should lie alone so long:
With that a gallant comes, gallants can do
Much with young maids,

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And with old women to.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.l: He courted me once, and again, and thrice,
'Tis virtue to say nay, to be too nice
Agrees not with my humour, yet some say,
We maids wish things, to which we answer nay,
Briefly methought he stood so long a-wooing ,
I rather could a wished he had been doing
Some other business, yet at last we 'greed,
'Twere strange if earnest suitors should not speed.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: In what agreed you?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: In our wedding ring,
Time, place, and hour, indeed in every thing:
The day appointed, and each thing in frame,
I thought each hour an age until it came,
Well, come it is, the morning once in sight,
I thought it ten times longer till 'twas night.
At dinner time methought I swelled with pride
To be drunk to by name of mistress Bride,
Music spoke loud, no delicates were scant,
Yet still methought another thing did want,
For sure thought I, there's something in a man
That wife's love well, hope brides may wish it than.
Long looked for comes at last, to bed we go.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Would I had dreamt I might ha' done so to.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: My bed-mate turned, and as he would ha' spoken
I sweet with fear, and in that fear I woke,
But seeing my kind bedfellow was gone,
Lord how it chafed me that I waked so soon,
One minutes dreaming longer, I had tried,
The difference twixt a virgin and a bride.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.l: O 'twould ha' vexed a saint, my blood would burn
To be so near, and miss so good a turn.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: And so did mine to I warrant you, nay though I be but a little pot, I shall be as soon hot as another.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You should not be my sister else.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nor my mother's daughter neither.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: And in good earnest we are not fathered much amiss.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Are you aviâd of that, and i'faith tell me, what think you of your servant Dorus.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: As of a sweet almond in a rugged shell, the sun in a cloud, or a wealthy diamond in a rock, indeed clean contrary to the world, he wears the worst side outward, and is much better than he seems: but what think you of your manly Amazon.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: Nay the sport is I know not what to think, Zelmane's humour would afford project for a pretty court comedy, my father courts her for a woman, and as I fear she is, my mother dotes upon her for a man, and as I wish he were, and that with such an ardour of affection, that I could find in my heart to turn my mother out of the company, and play the lover's part myself.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: however man or woman, the jest holds currant in one.

sp.speaker: Vio.
sp.p: I know not what knavish motion hath had to do with my thought, but my mind tells me that your servant Dorus and my Amazon, are other than they seem: and here he comes.

div.stage: Enter first Lisander, then Miso, Mopsa, Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Why how now madam, ladies gadding, is this the obedience of your father's charge.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Pardon mistress Miso, 'twas my doing and the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Miso
sp.p: But the Duchess will like neither the Duke's doings nor yours neither in this case I can tell you. The Duke stays your coming and yet the Duchess is very desirous on't, my husbands is in the next arbour to man you. For you lady, my presence be your privilege.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p:
Miso should be either a hangman or a herald, for she never
comes amongst us, but she quarters our company and arms.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Excellent beauty, and therefore more excellent, because situate in so fair a creature.

sp.speaker: Mops.
sp.p: You are a merry man Dorus, but all this cannot make me think you love me, how say you mother doth he.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Marry let him chose daughter, when I was as thou art.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were as she is, but faith madam Mopsa, I perceive my servant Dorus bears a month's mind to you, be not so straight laced to him. Mop. Straight laced, sgod mend me I am not laced at all, am I Dorus, no in sooth, I go wide ope Wednesday, I never lace myself but on Sundays, and that for fear I should burst with eating of plum porridge. Hip. I mean let fall some comfortable looks on your suitor.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Sgod mend me I'll let fall or take up any thing I have to do him good.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Why that's kindly said, and Dorus your love is very ambitious, to climb so high as the beautiful Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: O are you advised of that, 'twould make a horse break his bridle to hear how the youth of the village will commend me, o the pretty little pincking nyes of Mopsa says one, o the fine flat lips of Mopsa says another, and then do I bridle my head like a malt-horse thus, set mine arms a kembo thus, wreath my neck and my body thus, wink with one eye thus, and spread my peacocks tail as broad as the proudest minx of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: These extraordinary graces must not want admiration, but where's your mother.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Speak softly in the lobby there, for waking my lady's foisting hound.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Godsme, my mother's stealing of a nap.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: Nay, she cannot be said to steal a nap, for the noise she makes herself would discover her theft: but Dorus sith your fortunes are poor, you should study to ennoble your deserts, and beget effects worthy to court and win your lady's acceptance.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p:
Lass madam, I choose no better moderater than yourself, betwixt me and my unworthy services, suppose yourself though but a cuckoo compared with this sweet singing nightingale, should be sued to by a prince like me, I mean like me in love, for love in princes and peasants admits comparison: suppose Demetrius should in like disguise court you as I do, Mopsa, sigh for you, as I do, for Mopsa, kneel to you thus, as I do, to Mopsa, lay down his life to you, as I do, to Mopsa, prefer your good before his own, as I protest I do, Mopsa's, suppose he should show you the known mark of his neck, to assure
you he were Demetrius, as I do this to Mopsa, to witness I am the son of Menalchas, could your disdain stand out like Mopsa's?

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: What a keen necessity sets upon the edge of invention, trust me Mopsa your servant speaks well, and if he can prove himself the man he speaks of, and my wishes well hope, Demetrius, you have no reason to think scorn of him.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Why what should I do madam, my mother tells me I must not say as I think.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I am no counsellor, but should Demetrius in like disguise court me, thus would I embrace him, thus seal my affections with a kiss, and thus argue: think not Demetrius that the clouds of baseness could so muffle thee, but that the sun of valour shined through them long since, and in regard of thy serviceable duty in concealing, and unpresented policy in thus making known thy love, sort but out fit opportunity, and in despite of all guardians strict observance, go where thou wilt, the worth of Demetrius shall draw Hippolita, this would I vow, and this will I perform.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: And were I Demetrius and you Hippolita, I would deceive Dametas, outreach Miso, forswear Mopsa, and forsake Archadea to share the fortunes of divine Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And what should I do then?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I do but speak in the person of Demetrius, and under Hippolita shadow what I intend to the rare, and never enough wondered at Mopsa, the black swan of beauty, and madge-howled of admiration.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Do not you flout me Dorus, and you do not, provide a priest and I'll marry you, and my father and mother shall never know one.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Manasses is the man.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: And I'll be the woman, whosoever say nay to't, little dreams my mother of what we have done.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: 'Tmay be she did, for she sighed and ground much in her sleep.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: 'Tis well she was so quiet, for she eat pease porridge to breakfast, and they'll make me break wind in my sleep like a horse, and see as the devil will hate she wakes, and here comes my father, no words and ye love me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why god a mercy Dorus, this diligence becomes the servant of Dametas, and I'll prefer thee fort.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: You were worse than the devil else, for they say he helps his servants, than you may do little and you cannot help yours.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Will you break your jests against the bars of you chamber window, and clear the green, the Duke is coming to bowls, and I would not for half mine office you should be a rub in the way of his
patience: daughter and wife, conduct her to the lodge. Exit.and Dorus. make you haste about your business.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.l: I warrant you sir: be my hopes rightly placed?
You will condemn me for my too much haste.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: Why so: this 'tis to be in authority: inferior persons, I and the princes themselves, fly from my presence, like the chirping birds from the sight of the falcon: my very breath like a mighty wind blows away inferior officers (The court rubbish) out of my way, and gives me a smooth passage: I am the morning star, I am seldom seen but about the rising of the sun: indeed I am never out of the Duke's eye; and here he comes.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Doth our match hold.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Yes, whose part will you take.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Zelmane's.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Soft, that match is yet to make.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Let's cast a choice, the nearest two take one.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: My choice is cast, help sweet occasion.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Come, here's a good.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Well, bettered.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Best of all.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: The Duke and I.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: The weakest go to the wall.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I'll lead.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I'll follow.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: We have both one mind.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: In what?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In leaving the old folk behind.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Well jested daughter, and you lead not fair,
The hindmost hound, though old, may catch the hate.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Your last bowl come?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: By the faith a me, well led,

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Would I might lead you,

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: To my bed.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I am sure you would not?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: By this air I would.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I hope you would not hurt me, and you should.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I'd love you sweet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Sour, so I heard you say.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Accept it then.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Of what acquaintance pray?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Of loves, and mine.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Daughter, your bowl wins one.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: None of my maidenhead father, I am gone,
The Amason hath won one.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yield to that.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The cast I do.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Yourself?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Nay scrape out that.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Whose is it yet?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: The Dukes: play smooth and fine,
The smallest help that is, will make your mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Me yours?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Your mine, for though the cast I lose,
I ha' won your love.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Much: in my tother hose.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Come, the last market this cast is worth all the rest.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: The leader as the follower.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.l: Badd's the best,
I win her for ten crowns, and there they be.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: I take your lay.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A match twixt you and me.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: I'll be your half.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: That were unkindly done.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Pardon me mother, I'll bear all or none.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I ha' won you madam.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Me?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: I mean your bet.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then take your winnings, I'll not die in debt.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Madam believe me, I am as I protest, a prince, my name Lisander.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Look to the Duke's standing madam.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: So I will I warrant you, and to your falling.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p:
Thus clouded as you see, for your love, my soul speaks in my tongue: I appointed this match at bowls a purpose to acquaint
you with it.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Bar stealing father; yet and all hit right,
Here's one would steal a piece of flesh tonight .

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Dear madam.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: No more words, I have perceived as much in your eye, as you can express with your tongue, and as far as my mother's jealousy would give me leave, answered it with kind looks: your bias stands wrong mother.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Why? It stands towards Zelmane's.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Hath it stood so long?

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: All the game through.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Then all your game's bold wrong: furnish you with necessaries befitting an escape, and my will shall be as ready to take wing, as yours; put in a cast now mother, or the game is gone indeed.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: Whose is the throw?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Ours, till the last bowl came.
But that hath wont'em clear, both cast and game.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Our winnings come, a kiss and bate the rest.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: What do you kiss in earnest or in jest?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In earnest in good truth.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Troth, kindly said,
Take heed you kiss not out your maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: In jest?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: In earnest.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: 'Tis the fashion,
Much in request among our nation.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: To kiss away their maidenheads?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.l: Now and then,
And being gone, to kiss it back again:
For lovers indentures are ne'er fairly drawn,
Until the maidenhead be left in pawn,
As earnest of the match, so mothers said,
And so will daughters do when mams be dead.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What? pawn their maidenhead?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Yes, and lose 'em too.

sp.speaker: Dutch.
sp.p: And you'll maintain that fashion?

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Signior no.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Lay by this homebred mirth, and prepare your ears to entertain strangers.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Stranger? why father, strangers are as welcome to me, as mine own countrymen; if they bring good manners, and civil humanity in their company: otherwise, they are like foul weather, come afore they be sent for.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Dometas, nay then we shall have news enough; for he never comes into the presence, but he brings a whole sack full of ãâ¦ã es: of news I should say.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Welcome Dametas: what officious fellow is that?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A pure well-willer of your majesties, and a follower of mine.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: O 'tis Manasses; and he could make arms as well as he mars legs, he would grow in great request for heraldry: what's your news?

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: These LacedÃ¦monians, subjects to your majesty, having a message to deliver to your majesty's instruments of hearing, commonly yclept, ears.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: How? Hath any one here, clipped ears?

sp.speaker: Manas.
sp.p: Sweet feminine, clip off the tail of thy discourse with the scissors of attention, as I say, these LacedÃ¦monians have chosen me their tongue.

sp.speaker: Viol.
sp.p: Of a long tongue thou speakst very little.

sp.speaker: Mana.
sp.p: That proves me no woman, for they speak over much.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: What grievances oppress them? briefly speak.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Merchandise (My ledge) through the avarice of purchasing officers, is racked with such unmerciful impost, that the very name of traffic grows odious even to the professor.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Towns so oppressed for want of wonted and natural liberty, as that the native inhabitants seem slaves, and the foreigners free denizens.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Offices so bought and sold, that before the purchaser can be said to be placed in his office, he is again by his covetous patron displaced.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Common riots, rapes, and wilful homicide in great men's followers, not only, not punished, but in a manner countenanced and applauded.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: Indeed since your majesty left the land, the whole body of the commonwealth runs clean against the bias of true and pristine government.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: And your honourable brother, like a ship tossed upon the violent billows of this insurrection, by us entreats your majesty's letters of speedy reformation, for fear the whole kingdom suffer inevitable shipwreck.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Which after short deliberation with our counsel, yourself shall return. Dametas, reward their travails with 200. Crowns: in the mean time, let 'em taste the best entertainment of our court.
sp.l: Proud rebels, they shall see that a Duke's frown,
Can at his pleasure, turn rebellion down:
See them rewarded.

sp.speaker: A ãâ¦ã i
sp.p: Manasses, see the fellows entertained; I must attend of the Duke.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Boy, see the fellows entertained? I must wait of my lord.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Fellows, be as merry as you may, I must follow my m.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: So, here's petitioners attendance right; good words, and short commons: but 'tis not their entertainment we come for. I made a simple shift to get entertainment into the court,

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Well Cupid, pray for our lives, for and we were gone, I know not where thou wouldst have two such statesmen again.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: His commonwealth could not stand without us: and that his mother knows well enough: and he sends no better success than we had at our hunting, he loses a friend of me.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: 'Twill not sink in my thought yet, but that old musty slave Dametas played the slave with us.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: Would I could prove it once: but since we are again admitted our realm, shall we be idle? somewhat we'll do, though they'll give us but small thanks for our labour.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: The Duke shall not say his daughters are so ill beloved, but we'll change a thrust or two with his intent for 'em.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: 'Twould put the poor wenches out of conceit with themselves, and there should not be some contending for 'em.

sp.speaker: Jui.
sp.p: We are in the way to catch the old one, and then our aim deceives not.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.l: We are i'faith: invention could not weave,
A quainter web, suspicion to deceive.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p:
Come, pass off this groveling imitation; a lover's
thoughts must be ambitious, and like the eagle, scorning the base air where kites and crows lie flagging: mount the clear sky of invention, and overpeer all hindrances:
sp.l: The ladies themselves are willing.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Ready to embark upon the next tide of occasion whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Let me alone to work it then. But here comes my boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: 'Twere more for your credit sir, and you could say your man: but men and war were worn out of fashion both in a summer.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: I am of thy belief in that, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Would my lord were so to, sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Suppose I were sir what then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I should (As many upstarts have done) prove rich: for I believe you would make me your heir.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Is that part of your belief?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A principal point sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Renounce it then, for I believe you'll never be saved by't.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am sure I cannot lose by't. I believe further, that many knights, and some ladies, were never of gods making.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Of whose then, wag?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I'll tell you: the minters quoin gold, gold makes heralds, heralds make knight, and knights stamp ladies.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: And what do ladies?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They live not idly neither; they make some knights, and mar many gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
