sp.p: Ladies are good workwomen too, then?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Far better than any tailor: they'll make you an end of a suit, especially a court suit, when all the tailors in a country know not how to set a stitch in't.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I am of the belief you are a knave, sir.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I had no say, should I say you were not.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Well, what, a knave?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: In a knave's belief sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Because in yours?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Do you say't, and I'll swear't, my lord.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: No more boy, I am weary of your jests.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: That confirms 'em to be good sir.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Your reason for that, sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Because travellers and lovers, are soon weary of goodness.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Goodly ones in deed: but leaving this highway of circumstance; I sent you for Manasses.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The learned scribe attends you.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Will you fall off, sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Like an apple at Michaelmas, without shaking.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Welcome Manassas: I have present employment for thee, in which I must borrow

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Pardon me madam, I learned of my lord, to lend nothing without security and pawns.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: 'Tis not money (Manasses) but counsel and furtherance that we desire.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Good counsel is worth good money, madam.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Thou shalt be well considered; there's twenty crowns in earnest.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay madam, this hand's like a fellow, it takes every thing in jest; if you be in earnest, let me feel it here: so lady, now betwixt earnest and jest, if your will be ready drawn, before your friend delivered as your deed, and put me in trust to execute it.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Take't, in a word this honest shepherd, and thy lord's daughter madam Mopsa, are man and wife.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Man, an woman perhaps; but not man and wife: for though most women have a will to be ladies, like my lords wife; yet every lady have not wit to be a wife, as my lord's daughter. But what good can I do in this?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: O very much: for though they be man and wife by oath and protestation, the chiefest ceremony of all; namely marriage, is yet unperformed, and hearing that you have ta'en orders.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: That I have: I have ta'en order for the making away of a hundred maidenheads in my time, and not so few: but I am in in the mind of you now, these two beagles, Dorus and Mopsa, have run themselves breathless in the chase of love, you would ha' me couple 'em up in the leases of matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: You are in the right.

sp.speaker: Manass.
sp.p: And you in the wrong, I'll keep your jest, but in any case take back again your earnest: I'll not purchase my lords displeasure with your gold.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: Thy lord shall never know't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O sir! though my m. hath but bad eyes, he hath exceeding long ears: and though a forrayner may play with a citizen's wooden dagger, I would not wish any to jest with a courtier's steeled sword; 'tis seldom drawn but it draws blood.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Tush man, be not so timorous, my credit shall countenance thee: be not an ass, make use of thy time: thy master's service is no heritage; the world knows he gets under the Duke, thou art a fool, and thou wilt lose under him: there's a hundred crowns for thee; tush man, thy betters will strain curtsy with allegiance for a bribe.

sp.speaker: Mana.
sp.p: Madam, could you to every one of these crowns give me a kingdom,

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I should ha' more ground than half the Kings in Christendom: here's my hand, I'll do't: my m. is my m. and I love him; but my gold's my God, and I honour it: I'll do't; the time and place?

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Soon in the evening at Adonis chapel. Art resolute?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.p: As your adamant: think you was fear made me keep out? no was hope of these flattering sweet lipped drabs, I fear to marry my lady's daughter? no nor to go to bed with her neither. Why, I have counterfeited his hand and seal. He has been content with me, to come nearer to him, at his entertainment of the last ambassador, when he was heat with drinking of healths. As I led him to his chamber, I nimmed his chain, and drew his purse, and next morning persuaded him he lost it in the great chamber at the revels. He puts me in trust with his whole estate: he buys manners, I purchase farms: he builds houses, I pluck down churches: he gets of the Duke, and I of the commons: he beggers the court, and I beggar the whole country.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: These are notable knavish courses. What breeding hast had?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Very good breeding sir: my great grandfather was a rat-catcher, my grandsire a hangman, my father a promoter, and myself an informer.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Thou wert a knave by inheritance.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
And by education too: but bawdy informations growing stale, I gave up my cloak to a broker, and crept into credit for a gown, and of Manasses a penurious informer, I turned
copy, and became Manasses, a most, precise, and illiterate expositor.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: Were you a reader then?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And a writer too bully; I set some of my parishioners wives such copies, as their husbands might cast their caps at it, but could never come near.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: But and you used such a high and elevate style, your auditories low and humble understandings should never crawl over't.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Tush I could fashion the body, of my discourse fit to the ear of my auditor: for to cast eloquence amongst a company of stinkards, is all one as if a man should scatter pearl amongst the hoggish animals yclept swine: no I had paraphrastical admonitions of all sorts; some against covetous landlords, and that would I squirt amongst beggarly tenants: some against usurers, and that would I throw in at prison grates amongst prodigal banquets: some against the pride of the court, and that honeys the ear of the citizen: some against the fraud of the city, and that's cake and cheese to the country: some against Protestants, and that's plumps the lazy Catholic against papist and protestant, and that fattens the rank witted puritan, against papist, puritan, and protestant; and that tickles the ear of the luxurious atheist.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Why you never light upon any atheists, do you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: O very many.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: In the country perhaps, and the outskirts of the city?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: In the very bosom of the city: and by your leave, here and there one in the court too: but we fiât 'em all; for in deed we wandering lights, have (As other tradesmen have) commodities of all sorts, and prizes.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: How do they come by them?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: As many do by offices, steal into them ere the Duke be aware of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Some buy 'em at booksellers stalls; but the best they bespeak of poets.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: methinks poets of all men, should not edify, they are so envious.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
One to another, to nobody else: a proud poet is for all the world like a punk in request, covetous of many clients, when she hath more than she can handsomely play off: you
shall have some poet (Apollo's vicar, especially) write you a comical, pastoral, tragical, musical history in prose, will make the auditor's eyes run a water like so many waterspouts: I had one of them myself, and your ears be in case, I'll give you a taste on't; his argument was fetched out of the poem called, the lost sheep: and thus it is.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Prithee be brief?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay peace, and it were in place where you might wake, the best men in the parish, for commonly they sleep the beginning, because they love not division: but to the lost sheep. Beloved, you must imagine this sheep was a sheep, a lost sheep; a sheep out a the way: but my dear flock and loving sheep, whom like a careful shepherd, I have gathered together with the whistle or pipe, as it were of mine eloquence, into this sold of peaceful community; do not you stray do not you fly out, do not you wander, do not you lose yourselves; but like kind sheep, and valiant rams: I speak to you the better part and head of my flock. As I say, you shall see the valiant rams turn all their horns together, and appose themselves against the wolf, the hungry wolf, the greedy wolf, the lams-devouring wolf, the wolf of all wolves, to defend their eawes and young ones. Dared you say all your heads together, and with the horns of your manhood defend your families, your own wives, and your neighbour's children: was not this stinging gear?

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: A good sheepish admonition.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The fitter for my audience: while you live, have a ear to fit your audience.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Thou speak'st like a christian: prithee what religion art of?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How many sooner I make use of, I'll answer with Piavano Orllotto the italian: I profess the Duke's only.

sp.speaker: Demet.
sp.p: What's his reason for that?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: A very sound reason: for says he, I came raw into the world, and I would not willingly go roasted out, so close up the stomach of your discourse with that dry answer, and every man about his business.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You'll be mindful of to morrow-night.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: As your lawyer of the term, or your landlord of the quarter day.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Why so: the mettle I must forge my plot on, lies a warming in the furnace of my brain; and I must fashion it instantly, for fear it burst the heat. Give my conceit way, for here comes one must help to proportion it.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: How now Demetrius, what wind hath blown up this storm of melancholy, thy countenance was not wont to be thus cloudy? Whence proceeds this sudden alteration?

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: From mine own hard fortune my lord, that my ill-starred nativity should continue thus opposite.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Art crossed in a suit at court? or what's the matter? speak.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I'll acquaint your honour: I hope no other ear overhears us, under Diana's oak I found an inscription upon a stone, which told me, that wealth Aristomeres sometimes brought into Archa , had there under hid a massy sum of treasure.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Under Diana's oak? Dorus shall have my daughter Mopsa: no more words on't, and thou lovest me Dorus: smother thy golden hops a day or two; thou shalt have Mopsa, but I'll have all the gold, then marry my daughter to some great man, though he be poor, 'tis the fashion: I'll be nobly allied whate'er it cost me: shalt be my son in law Dorus: have an eye to the Princess, fall close to my daughter Mopsa,
sp.l: Court her and spare not: now begins the sport,
Kiss her, do kiss her; thou shalt pay sweetly fort:
I can gull you, know what fair words can do,
I'm an old knave, and a young courtier too.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: So, so; how violently he devours his bane, and steals himself into the order of gullery: methinks I see how betwixt hope and fear he sweats in his practice, and like a foolish dreamer, casts how to lay out his wealth before it comes in. So much for him: now to my lady beauty his wife; and as the devil would ha're, here she comes.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Dorus, how now Dorus 'What time a day is't with you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What time a day soe'r't be with me, 'tis sleeping time with my lord, I'm sure of that.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Sleeping time Dorus, what dost thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay nothing: he is troubled with a kind of malady called jusurectio carnis.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: How, a dish of crevices? nay and that be the worst, good enough: I am glad 'a falls to fish, for he was given to flesh a late too too bad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Mass I thought as much, for I saw him go a angling.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: I hold my ladyship to some strumpet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Life, a jealousy; I think you are a witch, was so indeed.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Nay I thought as much: he was wont to kiss me, and do all kindness a man could do, till he came to the court; and now he will not lie with me forsooth: and why? 'tis the court fashion. He will not love me, and why? 'tis the court fashion. I must not come near him at his down lying, nor his uprising, etc. And this be the court fashion, would I were an honest woman of the country again, be courtiers who list. Ay, ay, Dorus, I tell thee in tears, he hath not done by me, as a husband should do.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing to me, I cannot do withal madam, would I could.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Yes marry mayst thou Dorus; thou mayst, and shalt do withal too and thou wilt: but as thou lookest to enjoy my daughter Mopsa, acquaint me with the old foxes starting hole.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: That's passed my cunning: the old fox has more holes than one, to hide's head in: but not to go long about the bush with you.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: No good Dorus, I do not love a man should go long about my bush: what is she for a woman?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I know not what she is for a woman; marry I fear she's little better than a whore for your husband: hark in your ear; she's Manasses wife.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Manasses wife? marry fire master gunner; a Puritan turned punk: gods my precious. I'll slit her nose, as I am a lady will I: is she the party you wot on?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes faith madam, she is the mare the man rid on.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: I'll spoil their sport, saddle my mule there, have an eye to the Princess: shalt ha' my daughter and be but to spite him withal, faith fox I'll ha' you out of your hole, or I'll fire you out.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Nay that will do no good, but for your own good madam, take heed you do not scold.

sp.speaker: Mise.
sp.p: Why may not a lady scold Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Scold, oh in no case, 'twill mar a lady's beauty clean, and make her look as hard favoured at any ordinary woman.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Godamercy for that Dorus, I'll not lose my beauty for twenty on 'em: saddle my mule, bring me my chopping knife, I'll gold the lecherous goat, and mince his trull, as small as herbs to the pot. This is not scolding Dorus, is't?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No this is tolerable.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Nay then I care not, saddle my mule I say, let her pray God her feeling be good, for as I am a lady, I'll not leave her an eye to see withal, and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: O take heed of that at any hand, so, so, so: now it begins to quicken methinks , I see already how she runs a-tilt at the wenches eyes: calls the maid bawd, the woman whore, and her husband lecher: and when all comes to all, like an Irish wolf, she barks at her own shadow; but committing her and her ass to their wild-goose chase: now to my sweet heart Mopsa, for she's all the blocks last in my eye to stumble on: and God bless my wits, for the fool haunts me.

sp.speaker: Mops.
sp.p: Dorus, where's my father Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Your father, o my dear Mopsa?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay now you flout me?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Flout you? o the fair heavens, but this 'tis for a man to cast away himself in violence of passion and extremity of sighs on a piece of beauty, that cares not for him, but it is the tricks on you all.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Tricks, no as god mend me, and I should not have a husband till I got him with tricks, I should lead apes in hell: but faith tell me, dost thou love me Dorus?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Do I love you quoth ye, it cuts my very heart strings, do I love you? why 'tis the only mark my inqeuors she or at.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: If thou dost not hit the mark, than thou'rt a very bungler: but where is my father?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why I have sent him and your mother out of the way of purpose, and appointed Manasses to meet us this evening at Adonis' chapel in the Amasons apparel, to marry us: I think this are signs I love you.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I but you jest, I doubt you will not marry me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Will you mere me there?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I am a virgin I will.

sp.speaker: Dor,
sp.p: And come with an intent to marry me?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I hope to be a wife I will.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You must take heed you keep our purpose close,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: As I did the loss of my maidenhead.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why have you lost it then?

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Many a dear day ago, yet I told nobody on't but my mother and our horsekeeper, and they say I am never the worse maid for that, and I can keep my own counsel, as I hope I shall; but will you meet me soon?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Just in the midway, as tilters do.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I'll go afore and stay, but do not deceive me, and you do, I'll show my father's horsekeeper all as God mend me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: So tria sequntur tria, now am I rid of a triumviry of fools,
And by there absence have won a free access to an escape.
If my Lisander's hope prove like to this,
This night shall crown us monarchers of our bliss.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: No more of these delays sweet madam, your love hath broken day oft with my expectance, I dare give it trust no longer.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I confess it my liege, and like a spent deer, not able to maintain longer flight, I cast myself down breathless at your love's mercy: yet I beseech your majesty, let not your eager desires, practise any present violence upon my yielding chastity: 'twas only possession of my love you had in chase, which with convenient time and place purchased, I put your grace in full possession of.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p:
Although thy breath be never but musical, yet it never taught the string of true happiness till now: and to approve thy
heart sets hand to thy word, appoint the time.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Then this present evening (And yet my virgin blood, and ashamed to consent to the betraying of my modesty) meet me at Adonis' bower, where I'll make tender of subdued chastity to your high majesty, as my first and most victoriuos conqueror.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: By my imperial globe, and hope of those joys, thy presence shall bring to enrich me with, I'll meet thee, and make thee Queen over the most submiss captive that ever love took prisoner.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: If you deceive me.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Not except warm life,
Deceive my voice of their innative heat.
Then haste slow time, exchange thy leaden fleet,
For hormes wings till I my fair hopes meet.
But locked once in the arms of my delight,
Cloth all the world in an eternal night.
And steed of morning when the sun should rise,
They shall see two in my Zelmane's eyes.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.l: So farewell thought I, I have prepared you a Zelmane's answerable to your expectation.
Then triumph in thy will, and let thy thoughts
Proclaim a jubilee: my teeming hope:
Are now delivered of a gracious birth,
Which I have christened, opportunity.
Unto whose shrine in honour of this day,
My thoughts shall hold a monthly sacrifice,
Love grant Demetrius, meet the like success,
Our pains are crowned with double happiness.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Only our disguises hold firm, but all other attempts meet untimely deaths, even in their cradles.

sp.speaker: Amin.
sp.p: What and we should acquaint the ladies with our intents.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p:
'Twould argue a kind of cowardice in our wits, that ha' such suspectless admittance to there presence, as this disguise hath purchased us, we should not have that ability of inventure to entangle 'em
in their own security.

sp.speaker: Amint.
sp.p: Well howsoever, we must not dwell long determining for the liberty of stay with Dametas, who out of his covetous disposition in detaining our reward, allowed us the eldest day of our licent abode at court, is run out.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, and for my part, I'll rather go home with a private repulse, then managing any unlikely attempt, become sufferer under a public disgrace.

sp.speaker: Ami
sp.p: That's my very thought, yet that our second arrival be not altogether empty of employment, let's practise something upon Dametas, and acquaint the world with his coward baseness; in which, he not only detracts from his master's bounty, but look how as conduit head or master-spring that is poisoned, doth his best, to infect the whole body of the court, with the leprosy of his covetousness.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: There's no action of his begetting can be said to be truly honourable.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: How can they when there father's a mongrel, the Duke out of his honourable bounty commanded him to reward our travails with 200. Crowns: and now after two months attendance, and enforced delays: in which time an ordinary petitioner might have spent the value of the reward, he packs us off with 50. Crowns, his excuse being that his master hath forgotten us, and what he doth, is of his own bounty, as if the moon should brag she gave the world light, when all the luster she hath, comes from the heat of the sun.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: Should his villainies be suffered to prosper, they would grow to such height, as the Duke's authority should ha' much trouble to prune them.

sp.speaker: Ami.
sp.p: To prevent which, his majesty shall have private note of it, knew we in whose trust to conduct it.

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: 'Tis an office very few dare undertake, he is so riveted to the Duke's good opinion.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Lies there no jar twixt none of the nobility and him, what say you Zelmane's?

sp.speaker: Juli.
sp.p: The gallant, Amason: you could not ha' cast your choice fitter, for her honourable mind maintains deadly feud against his base proceedings: and here she comes, attended by Dametas' servant, let's wait on opportunity.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: Lisander.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: Demetrius.

sp.speaker: Iulo.
sp.p: Lisander and Demetrius, stand close, of my life we are come to the birth of some notable knavery.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: How blows the winds of our hopes?

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.p: Fair to the point of our expectation, I have made away the Duke and the Dutch.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: How made away them? poisoned them.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: With a confection of love, which I have so tempered with fair promises, as their minds are in love's heaven already: videlicet in Adonis bower, where this evening I have given 'em my word to meet 'em; but I have so cast it, that Manasses shall meet 'em in my steed.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: 'Twill be a rare scene of mirth, to hear what costly discourse the I'll bestow upon the fool in thy outside.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Do you hear that.

sp.speaker: Ilipo.
sp.p: Yes, thank love and my ears, but list the conclusion.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: I have cleared the way to Violetta, but what order hast thou ta'en, with thy burbolts: Dameta, Myso, and amorous Mopso.

sp.speaker: Damet.
sp.p: Shot 'em away, at three several marks, yet so conveyed it that in the end they shall all meet at Adonis' chapel.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: This project cannot but bring forth some notable deceit.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: My hopes should want of thyer will, and it do not.

sp.speaker: Lisand.
sp.p: Now we have made a smooth passage to our escape, how shall convey our lover out of the island.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: I have determined of that sir, and better to effect, my boy this time hast cast such a bait of knavery to the two captains, Kalader and Philinax, as we may pass without suspicion.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: But how for transportation.

sp.speaker: De.
sp.p: I am furnished of that to, you remember the two Lacedemon intelligencers

sp.speaker: Ilip.
sp.p: Now what of us.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: Hold my life, we shall be put in this scene of gullery.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: O in any case.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: For the love of Cupid do, inquiries past, let's take our entrance, and pass over the stage like mules, to furnish out a show.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p:
And see occasion like a kind wench presents 'em in the very instant my honest friends welcome, have you not your dispatch
with a letter to Lacedaemon.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Madam we have, and stay only to take our leaves of your ladyship, and know what service your honour will command.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: You have my thanks, for the truth is, I must commit business of much import unto your trust, and to prevent much circumstances take my word, you are not ignorant of the Kings general challenge.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: About his daughters.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: You understand me, with these few crowns receive my mind which is to convey the 2, ladies whom we in these disguises have won to Lacedaemon,

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: Were we but confirmed of your of estates.

sp.speaker: Lis.
sp.p: We'll give your sufficient assurance of that and the Princesses themselves shall confirm it.

sp.speaker: Julio,
sp.p: We crave no better madam, but shall we not ha' yours honour's company.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: No: having brought them aboard, we'll make return to the Duke, to let him understand we stole not our prizes but won them manfully at the point of wit.

sp.speaker: Amt.
sp.p: A noble resolution.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.p: His foil will appear the more palpable, and your conquest the more applausable, where shall we receive the ladies.

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Be that our care, but on your lives be heedful of your safe ties.

sp.speaker: Amt,
sp.p: More than of our own my lord,

sp.speaker: Dem.
sp.p: Enough whilst you attend we'll to the Duke, and play all gulls or none.

sp.speaker: Julio.
sp.l: All gulls indeed since you had follies whip,
No gulls, to all gulls, fools love fellowship.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Look well to mine ass there, lord how I sweat with anger; this same's the house sure, and now like a wise lady let me count my hurts, and see how I shall be revenged: it shall be so, I'll have 'em both carted, and Manasses shall go afore like a whiffler and make way with his horns, where be these whores: open the door, where be these pan dear: oh that I were not a lady: I could scold like a butter-whore,

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Who's there a god's name, lord for his mercy is the woman mad.

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: Yes I thank ye fort: horn mad, where's your companion whetes the old lecherous goat my husband, open the door I say.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Jesus for thy mercy's sake madam, what do I want.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: What do I want, the chief implement a woman should have I want that as a woman cannot be without, I mean my husband, I want.

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: Your husband, I saw him not as I am an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.p: Not as you are an honest, so I think, but as you are an arrant whore you did, you must have your crevices with a pox cannot city manchet and fresh cod-serve your turn, but you must have court cakebread and crevishes with a vengeance, but come give me my husband, or I'll have him out of the flesh on thee, and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Pray madam ha patience: what should your husband do here

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: That which he should do at home with his wife, and he were worth his ears.

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: Lady I protest I do not know him,

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Not know him thou liest in every vain ith' heart thou liest, thou knowest him, and as Adam knew Eve thou knowest him, he hath been as inward with thee, as ever he was with me, he hath by his own confession he hath, and thou deniest it, thou liest in thy throat like a puritanical whore as thou art, oh that I were a butter-whore for an hour I might scold a little.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Madam they are no honest men that bring these tales to you

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: Men bring tales to me, I defy thee in thy guts, I defy thee, men bring tales to me, thou takest me to be one of thine own church dost: they are no honest men that bring tales to thee and ha wives of their own, and my husband's one of them, go thy ways now.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I beseech you madam do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Mis,
sp.p: Hear thee, I have heard too much of thee, too too much too much, where's my husband, bring forth my husband, I'll teach him to put a difference betwixt Joan and my lady I hold him ten pound on't, and yet I will not scold neither, and I had been an old hag passed teeming as his whore is a Puritan, it had bid somewhat, but being a woman of gods making, and a lady of his own, and wearing mine own hair which is much in a lady of my standing I can tell you, to use me thus, flesh and blood cannot endure, let me come in, open the door let me come in, oh that I were any vile thing in the world but a lady that I might scold a little.

div.stage: Enter Kalander and philanax Demet, boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: So so, so, take your places, for the same bald pated oak is the stage, where ye shall see the part of a doting fool performed by an old man and a young wench,
sp.l: Do worshipful Dametas,
The same man,
Hath he no fellow actors in his most lamentable, comical, historical, tragical, musical, pastoral.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: None that require any mouthing but his ass and himself, marry then he has signer Mattocke, a very sharp satirical humorist, and mounser le spade, but he goes somewhat more bluntly to his business, yet he'll serve for mutes, and as good as the best to furnish out the stage.

sp.speaker: Kal,
sp.p: But dares Dorus being but Dametus servant so abuse his mad master thus grossly.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: O lord sir, their ha been serving men have done their masters far greater abuse, yet had their wives concealed it, their ears should never have been acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is that a fashion in request.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Altogether I'll assure you, but obedience gentleman the scene begins.

div.stage: Enter Damet as with mattock and spade

sp.speaker: Kal
sp.l: Pray God it be good he stays so long,
Ridiculous enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Dame.
sp.p: So, stand ass, stand gentle ass.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: What countrymen is his ass he speaks so familiarly to him.

sp.speaker: Boy
sp.p: Ath' city breed, marry he picks up his living ath' burrs and nettles that grow about the court gate.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Be in readiness good mattock, play thy part sweet spade, let me see Diana's oak? I held Diana's oak divine, true pure gold honest, Dorus, fortunate Dametas.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.p: An excellent comedian , what life he puts into his part.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: So, by thy leave stone, by thy patience honest stone, the very gravel savours of treasure, this same's the bed chamber of my lady Pecunia, and see, see some of her golden hairs, more, more, more yet divine tree, pure gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, softly, softly, not to fast, let me not devour my content too greedily least like a cormorant I take a surfeit on't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: O take heed of that master in any case.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p:
Pure mettle, excellent gold: but let me see now, I shall by computation have some three millions of them, I some three or four millions, how shall I employ 'em to make the most profit of
'em.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: That would be known indeed.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: I'll put out one million to use, after the rate of seven score to the hundreth: and yet I won't, no fie, for then you will ha' my humour brought ath' stage for a usurer; to prevent with scandalous report, I'll put it into my scribe-majors hand, and he shall deal for me.

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: There's is a simple cloak to cover his villainy.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: 'Tis a very short one,: and passing 'slight to hide his knavery.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: It cannot choose but be seen through,

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: another million I'll lay to bestow in offices. I will have wealth or I'll rake it out ath' kennels else, chimneys ha' smoked for already, and now I'll deal upon sea-coal and salt, now, now, now, it comes, sweet gold, honest Dorus, fortunate Demetrius, divine gold, how, how, shall I adore thee, oh let me do the homage of my knees: now now, for the tongue of a poet, though I hate poetry worse than any of the seven deadly sins, I could wish myself a poet for some hour, to write a poem in the praise of my divine mistress; and see the very bed wherein her divinity is lodged: happy, happy, thrice

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Happy Dametas, now like an o'erjoyed lover, let me open the sheets of my heavenly mistress, with reverence, so with humble reverence, and like a blushing lover that puts out the light ere he presumes to touch the bed of his love so let me darken the candles of my body, mine eyes, and first bless my hands with touching, next enrich mine ears with hearing, and lastly make happy my eyes with with seeing, and let them convey the joy down into the bosom of my thoughts, by degrees, softly by degrees.

sp.speaker: Phi:
sp.p: Did you ever see ass make such a ceremonious preparation

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Be not offended sweet mistress that I presume to touch.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: A fool's head of your own,

sp.speaker: Kal:
sp.p: Has 'a been at any cost of all this invocate for a coxcomb and a bell.

sp.speaker: Phil:
sp.p: Beshrew my judgement but he deserves it,

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: And his desert were ne'er so much, he could but bear away the bell, and so you say he doth:

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: A coxcomb and a bell, o indignity: damnable oke, vile and evil accurst Dorus, unfortunate Dametas, Diana I tell thee thou art no honest gods to use a gentleman thus. What here a writing, your help good spectacles, lend me your help good spectacles, some comfortable news good spectacles:
sp.l: Who hath his hire hath well his labours placed,
Earth thou didst seek, and store of earth thou hast.
He that vain hopes pursues for love of pelf,
Shall lose his wits and likely find himself,
Then think thy pains rewarded well,
Thou broughst the fool, bear back the bell:
Of other matters what ensues
Adonis' bower shall tell the news,
Villainous poetry, I am made a flat fool by poetry,
But though I can do 'em no further disgrace, my fatal curse,
A wronged gentleman's fatal curse dwell ever upon them, Diana
Hear me, and let my words find gracious acceptance.

sp.speaker: Kal.
sp.p: Hide your heads, the terrible curse comes like a stone upon you

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Rancour, spite, malice, hate, and all disasters,
Strengthen my faith against all protestors.
May their intents though pure as crystal glasses,
Be counted faults and capital trespasses,
Oh may their lives and laboured industry,
Though worthy of Apollo's plaud it be
The clearest thought in loyalty excelling
Be by some dor presented for libelling,
When they have writ a scene in which their brains,
Have dropped there dearest sweets, and their swollen veins,
Emptied their conduits of their purest spirit,
As they stand gaping to receive their merit,
In stead of plaudities their chiefest blisses
Let their deserts be crowned with mews and hisses:
Behind each post and at the gallery corners,
Sit empty gulls, slight fools and false informers,
Let some sly fox out of discretion's embers,
Term them the lands unnecessary members,
And like the dear when they have spent their breath,
To make King's sport let them betorn to death,
Even by their friends, 'twould set my thoughts a twanging
Might I but see one of them go to hanging.

sp.speaker: 1 Capt.
sp.p: A passing strange curse and no question he has travelled far for some of the rhymes,

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: He must travail further that finds any reason in't,

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p: No matter for reason theirs rhyme enough and that be good.

sp.speaker: 2 Cap.
sp.p: Some: of it is no better than it should be, or my judgement deceives me.

sp.speaker: 1 Cap.
sp.p:
Sure he had some reason to make this rhyme,
and a man could pick it out,

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: Rather than I'll be counted inquisitive, mine ears shall content themselves with the rhymes only, and leave the reason to the scanning of poets whom it more nearly concerns.

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.p: But where's the wag that invited us to this banquet of mirth shrunk in the wetting?

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: 'Twere a rare jest now if whilst the boy kept us here in expectation of Dametas' gullery his m: had made an escape with the duks daughters,

sp.speaker: 1 captain
sp.p: That or some knavery else upon my life, I had the boy in shroud suspicion at the first.

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: And this his sudden and stolen departure, confirms it currant

sp.speaker: 2 captain
sp.p: Then we are sped, for in suspicion's face,
sp.l: I see some subtle stratagem in chase.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Will your lordship believe me now: nay and I say't your worship may swear't, though I have but a (Poor as to say) hole of mine own I hope the spirits have more denomination over me, than to make it a common slaughter house of carnality where every jack may command flesh for his money,

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: No more words sweet woman I confess I was in the wrong, there is not the hole the fox hides his head in: and therefore for the love of womanhood conceal mine errors, for howsoever I complained 'tis thy forehead aches, thy temples ha' the terrible blow as the say, thy husband is a bad man.

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: My husband:

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: Ay, ay, good woman thy husband: he is as I say a fleshly member and I fear he hath overcome the foolish thing my daughter.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Your daughter I'll slit her nose by this light and she were ten ladies, 'twas not for nothing my husband said he should meet her this evening at Adonis' chapel, but and I come to the godspeed on't, I'll tell 'em on't soundly?

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: I do good woman tell 'em on't, and spare not but in any case do not scold.

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Why may not a gentlewoman scold in a good case:

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: I know not what a gentlewoman do in a good case, but a lady must not in any case:

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Though I may not scold I may tell 'em roundly on't I hope,

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: That may you do law,

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: And I'll not be mealy mouthed I warrant 'em, will you bear me company to the chapel madam?

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Withal my heart mistress, what Dorus hath given me, I'll give my friend, no fool to company.

div.head: Actus quinti, scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter the Duke at adonis bower
div.l: Farewell bright sun thou lightner of all eyes
Thou falst to give a brighter beam to rise.
Each tree and shrub were trammels of thy hair,
But these are wire, for none but Kings to wear,
And my rude tongue striving to blaze her forth,
Like a bad artsman doth disgrace her worth,
But here's the place, upon this crystal stream:
Where Cytherea did unyoke her team
Of silver doves, to interchange a kiss
With young Adonis shall I meet my bliss:
The gentle minutes crowned with crystal flowers,
Losing there youths, are grown up perfect hours,
To hasten my delight, the bashful moon
That since her dalliance with Endymion,
Durst never walk by day is under sail,
In steed of sheets has spread her silver veil,
Each gliding brook and every bushy tree
Being tipped with silver were her livery,
And the dim night to grace our amorous wars,
Hath stuck nine spheres full of immortal stars,
Instead of pearls the way on which she treads
Is strew with crystal dew and silver beads.
She comes, her feet makes music with the ground,
And the chaste air is ravished with the sound,
My soul flies forth to meet her: hell my wife,
Her presence like a murderer drives the life
Out of my pleasure breast, her jealous eye
Envies the heaven of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Zelmane, or my husband life or hate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: What makes old autumn out a bed so late,
That snow should go a-wooing to the sun
When one warm kiss works her confusion.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: I have the jest, suspicion that keeps
Court in my husband's thoughts, seeing my love,
Elect this walk, hath brought him after him.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.p: She dogs her fure, and she to shake her off hath ta'ne some other walk I'll place mine ear in distance of her will.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Could I but hear the innocent delivery of his breath, 'twould be a second jubilee of mirth.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Here comes my love.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Your love? Alas poor Duke,
Your forward hopes will meet a barren spring,
My sun appears.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Fie your love speaks too loud,
Your suns eclipsed, your date upon a cloud.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: See how his arms like precious phoenix wings,
Spread to embrace me.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Now the cuckoo sings,
Those amorous arms do make a golden space
To hug a Duke.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: But I'll fill up the place.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Those fingers tipped with curious porphyry,
Staining Pygmalion's matchless imagery,
Like amorous twins all of one mother nursed,
Contend in courtesy who should touch me first.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Should touch me first: their strife is undertaken,
To twine a young bay not a far stooping oak.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.l: Young bay, stale jest, that a dry sapless rind
Should hold young thoughts, and a licentious mind,
Were he but gone now.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Were the Duke away,
My hope, had got the better of the day.

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: This is Adonis' chapel, I wonder they come not, though I bear a little learning about me, and a few good clothes, I would not wish 'em to make Balams ass a me: for though many fools take no felicity but in wearing good clothes (Though they be none of their own) I have a further reach in me.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: I could ban my stars.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: I curse my fate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: That cross me thus.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Make me unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: Alas good lady, how her pretty feet labour to find me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: That my hopes should meet such black events.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: O would the trindly night darken herself.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Would the moon lose her light,
That in the bosom of some foggy cloud
I might embrace my love.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: But night is purblind
To make a Duke a slave.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: To make a Duchess
Wrestle with amorous passions.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Life a spleen
Could my rough breath like a tempestuous wind,
Blow out heavens candles, leave the world stark blind,
That it might either have no eyes to see:
Or use those eyes it hath to pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Or use those eyes it hath to pleasure me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Who would ha' thought the cold had been so good a musician: how it plays upon my chaps, and maketh my teeth skip up and down my mouth like a company of virginal jacks, but I find small music in it, and Mopsa should come now I could do her little good, yet and she were here, she and I would have about at cob-nut or at cherry-pit or somewhat to keep ourselves from idleness, though she be but a fool, the babbles good enough to make sport with all in the dark and that very word hath started her.

sp.speaker: Mop,
sp.p: Who's there Manasses.

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: Yes Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Plain

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: I might be madam Mopsa in your mouth, goodman etc. where's Dorus.

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: Why because he will not be said to make too much haste to a bad bargain, he is not come yet,

sp.speaker: Mop,
sp.p: Not come, a peascod on him, but all's one I thought at first he would make but a fool on me.

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: Would you have him mend God's workmanship?

sp.speaker: Mop,
sp.p: But chose him, since he hath buld me with an urchin, I'll go fetch Raph our horsekeeper, let him that got the calf keep the cow in a knave's name and he will, ha you your book here.

sp.speaker: Man,
sp.p: No matter wench, I can dote well enough without book,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Nay and ye can dote well enough yourself, I care for neither of them both, but indeed I love to have a thing well done, for says my mother, a thing once well done, is twice done, and I am in her mind for that up and down,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: Who's with my lord the Duke, it cannot be,
Mine eye would not conceal such treachery.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: 'Tis not the Duchess sure, no it is amorous Jove,
That seeing Zelmane passionate for love,
Descends to comfort her, Jove if there be
A powerful Phoebus' god of poetry,
In dear remembrance of fair Daphne's rape,
To win my love, lend me some stranger shape,
Such as yourselves have worn, that when your fame
Is sung by poets, they may cote my name,

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Sure 'tis my daughter,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Daughter: how her eye
Cuts out new forms, new shapes of jealousy:

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.l: As sure as death 'tis she, for see they stand
Like amorous twins, entwisted hand in hand,
Breast against breast, and that no joy be missing,
To hear discourse, their lips keep time with kissing,
I'll not endure impatience grow strong,
And though a prince, tell him he doth thee wrong.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Do prithee do, this sweetens all the rest,
But here would be the elixir of the jest,
If whilst we kept each other at a bay,
A third should come, and bear the hare away.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Villainous poetry, unchristian like poetry, I am cozened of my gold by poetry, robbed of my charge by poetry, made an apparent fool by poetry villainous oak, accursed Dorus, unfortunate Dametas: who's there my daughter and with Zelmane? A well-willer to Dorus, a favourite to poetry, and therefore enemy to Dametas, come hither mop so, a thy father's blessing come not near her: what Mopsa.

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: Yes, who's there? Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Confusion a Dorus, I am thy miserable father, didst not see Hippolita,

sp.speaker: Mop.
sp.p: No by my troth not I? Did ye not see Dorus.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pox of Dorus I am undone madam and thou tellst me not of Hipolita,

sp.speaker: Mo,
sp.p: Pox a Hippolita, I am a dumb woman and you can tell me news of Dorus

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: I had rather see ten Doruses hanged then lose Hippolita,

sp.speaker: Mo,
sp.p: I had rather see ten fathers dammed then lose my sweet Dorus,

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: I shall run mad and I find not Hippolita.

sp.speaker: Mop:
sp.p: I shall run frantic and I find not Dorus.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: What's here, I shall run mad for Hipolita.

sp.speaker: Duke:
sp.p: And I shall run frantic and I find not Dorus, I hold my life we have some comedy in hand, we shall have a full scene, for here comes more actors.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: Assures I am a sinner to God madam, that same's he.

sp.speaker: Muso
sp.p: What with a brace of wenches, i'faith old brock, have I ta'en you in the manner, is this the fruits of your lying alone? is this your court custom with a wanion, lend me thy knife, though I had neither house, nor land to give 'em, I'll bestow a whore's make betwixt you and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: Mep:
sp.p: What a gudyere ail you mother, are you frampold, know you not your own daughter.

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: Mopsa, oh insufferable wrong, make thine own natural child thy bawd,

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Here's an excellent pattern for wives to learn to scold by

sp.speaker: Miso.
sp.p: What mistress Amason, ha you such a cocking spirit, honest women cannot keep their husbands at home for you: 'tis not for nothing now I see, that the Duchess looks yellow on you, but I'll tear that painted whores face of yours (By this light) and yet I will not scold neither.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Madam,

sp.speaker: Miso:
sp.p: I'll mad you with a vengeance.

div.stage: The Duke and Duchess step both forth and restrain her.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Touch not the prince.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: On your allegiance forbear, what means this outrage, cannot our private walks be privileged from your wild contentious.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: How fares the prince.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: How cheers my good Zelmane?

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: Zelmane, no gods my judge my liege, I am Manasses, miserable Manasses, your husband's scribe-major madam.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: Manasses.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: A fool.

sp.speaker: Mis.
sp.p: My man.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And my dear head, alas sweet love, what makest thou here.

sp.speaker: M,
sp.p: Marry work for the hangman, and the Duke be not the more merciful.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: There's some deceit in this, Dametas, where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Ay, ay, there's some knavery in this: Mopso where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Mis:
sp.p: Doubtless there's some villainy in this, Mepso where's Hipolita?

sp.speaker: Mep:
sp.p: There's no plain dealing in this, Manasses where's Dorus?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: Answer directly, where's Hippolita?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Alas madam I know not, whilst I almost melted myself with digging of gold in Diana's oak, I left her in my wife's charge

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: And whilst I ran to Manasses, thinking to take my husband and his wife in the manner, I left Hipolita in my daughter's chamber

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: And whilst I came to Adonis' chapel to be tossed in my marriage blankets with Dorus, I left my little dog pearl plucking daisies:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who sent you to diane's oak to dig gold?

sp.speaker: Gry:
sp.p: Who sent you to take your husband in Manasses house?

sp.speaker: Wife:
sp.p: Dorus.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Who sent you to Adonis' chapel.

sp.speaker: Mep:
sp.p: Dorus:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: And who turned you into this shape:

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: They that I fear have made gulls of us all, Zelmane, and Dorus:

sp.speaker: Duke:
sp.p: We are all simply gulled, and see where the sun scarce half ready, skips from his Eastern bed, smiling at our gullery:

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Come where's this lusty wit-master.

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: The keeper of this love-lottery,

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: This gallant luventus of fourscore, that like my lady of the lake, displays against all comers.

sp.speaker: Lisan.
sp.p: May a couple of plain witted princes have a sight of your prizes:

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Where be these ladies ha? ha your wits had such a skirmishing that the two maids have lost their heads in the conflict.

sp.speaker: Duchess;
sp.p: Heads, I and bodies to my lord, and all at one shot, and which is worse our wits are so scattered with the terrible blow that to be plain we are scarce our own men again.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Then you have had some knocking,

sp.speaker: Mun:
sp.p: So it appears by the story my lord:

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: How say you my lady, what owl sings out of that ivy bush

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Was your ãâã knighted in this last action:

sp.speaker: Man:
sp.p: I am ãâ¦ã ch a fool, I love my lord, I am no knight, I am Manasses, they made a plain fool.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: The only were, for the guarded fool is out of request: but faith my liege how did your opposites behave themselves, did they win the wenches fair at the point?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: At the very push of invention, and went off clear untouched,

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: And could you draw no blood of their wits:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Not a drop.

sp.speaker: Lisa.
sp.p: Nor demetrius neither, nor Manasses?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Neither, to our own disgrace be it spoken, the carriage of their stratagem deserves applause, and I held it a credit to rest captive to such valiant conquerors?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: Why so be, I like a man that will confess his error.

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: It merits commiseration madam and my liege, not to detract from our worth: your ear, we two are the parties you wot on.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Ware you the men?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: No he was the man, marry I was the woman in the moon, that made you walk all this last night like the man in the mist, I could say somewhat to you to madam as for demetrius and his man let them stand like fools as they are.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Can it be possible.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: No, no, we are gulls, innocent sots, but lante tanta, the girls are ours we have won 'em away to Dargison.

sp.speaker: Lisa:
sp.p: Come we have won the conquest, and that's sufficient.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: You are a Manasses 'tis not sufficient: aha not Hercules for Iole, Jove, for Danae, Apollo for Daphne, pan for Sirne, nay the whole pack of their piperly godheads could a discharged a stratagem with more spirit of all merit, an ambling nag and a down a down we have born her away to Dargison.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: 'Twas the most rarest, divinest, metaphisicalst, piece of invention, that, what say you my liege.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: I give your deserts their full merit you have gotten equality

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: All the wenches gave you:

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Alas what spirits under the moon could have detained her but know that her cherry red lip, a down, a down.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: Trust me but you have deserved high commendation.

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: Your merit stood of the upper stair of admiration.

sp.speaker: Dem:
sp.p: Why thou hast a pretty relish of wit, now that canst see the broad eye of my desert at a little hole of demonstration.

sp.speaker: Iulo.
sp.p:
Your desert save me free, you have done a most (To use your own
phrase) metaphysical piece of service, but you had some help in't questionless,

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: I do not think but the ladies had some hand in't:

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: A finger, I confess a finger by the hope of perseverance, a very little finger.

sp.speaker: Iuli,
sp.p: I thought as by the making of the jest.

sp.speaker: Hip,
sp.p: I cannot detract from the lady's worth, for I know 'em for excellent work women,

sp.speaker: Dam,
sp.p: Work women fit to make tailors men.

sp.speaker: Hip.
sp.p: I by my faith do I, nay your best tailors are arrant butchers to 'em, you shall have a lady make an end of a suit, a court suit, especially when all the tailors in a country know not how to set a stitch in't.

sp.speaker: Dorus,
sp.p: Some ordinary suit perhaps.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: Your best court suits that are, are finished by ladies, I have known a suit myself lain a making and maring 3, 4, and five year together and then a lady hath dispatched it in a month with a wet finger, such a finger might the ladies have in your plot.

sp.speaker: De,
sp.p: Never wet a finger by this sun.

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: Then she helped you with one dry jest or other, but and we may be so bold: faith where are the ladies?

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: Sure enough I warrant you, some fools now would have kept 'em hear and have been gulled on 'em again, and laughed at age, but to prevent all danger, we have shipped 'em home for Lacedaemon,

sp.speaker: Iulio:
sp.p: To Lacedaemon, your sun of wit shines but dimly in that methinks, to whose charge have you trusted 'em?

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: To them we durst, nay you must think we are no fools,

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.p: Fool's: nay deep wit, and policy forbid.

sp.speaker: Da,
sp.p: We had no sooner their surprisal, but we had disguise ready, a ship ready, a couple of lusty friends ready, the Lacedaemon's intelligencers:

sp.speaker: Iuli.
sp.p: Durst you trust such precious jewels in such rusty caskets:

sp.speaker: Da:
sp.p: Durst, our health, our lives: why they were my tenants, nay you must think we sifted them, we are no fools in that neither.

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: If in any thing your wits deserve the babble 'tis in that,

sp.speaker: Iuli:
sp.p: None but fools would have committed such inestimable peers to a couple of strangers:

sp.speaker: Hip:
sp.p: And in a ship to,

sp.speaker: Iu:
sp.p: And under sail to.

sp.speaker: Duchess
sp.p: And unfurnished of friends to.

sp.speaker: Du:
sp.p: And without shipping to follow 'em to.

sp.speaker: Junior
sp.p: You were no fools in any thing but that, and in that not to flatter, you express the true shape of folly and merely merit the name of fools.

sp.speaker: Da.
sp.p: What will you say now when these fellows surrender us our loves?

sp.speaker: Aunt
sp.p: We'll discharge you and set their names down for gulls in your stead.

sp.speaker: De:
sp.p: You know the proverb when the sky falls we shall have larks.

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: And when you can bring proof that we are cozened of our wenches we'll be the woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Julio:
sp.p: Why then we have once sprung a couple of woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Aunt:
sp.p: Do you know these? Who are the fools now?

sp.speaker: Deme:
sp.p: Violletta.

sp.speaker: Lisand:
sp.p: My Hippolita:

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What a strange change is here:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.p: Yes faith gallants you have very strange carding and you knew all, but I hope you'll offer up your cards and yield the set lost.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Gulls:

sp.speaker: Lisan:
sp.p: And abused I'll lose my life before I lose my honour,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Honour, and life before I'll lose my love:

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.p: Nay gentlemen we bar all violence, the liberty of our challenge was to all alike equally free, and since these by fair play have won 'em, it stands with our honour to see them peaceably possessed of 'em, then surely take 'em, for though you wear the breeches give us leave to stand a little:

sp.speaker: Hippo:
sp.l: Why father is't not time that we were sped
'Tis a great charge to keep a maidenhead,
Lose it we must and to prevent ill course,
Better to give't then have it stolen perforce,
If you be pleased let envy do her worst
Spit out her poison or contain and burst?
Welcome to all, to all a kind god night,
They truly live, that live in scorn of spite.

div.p: In B. the last page, for lord, read love cannot be saved.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
